Thomas Dekker 1572?-1632
The second part of the honest whore, with the hvmors of the Patient Man,
the Impatient Wife: the Honest Whore, perswaded by strong Arguments to
turne Curtizan again: her braue refuting those Arguments. And lastly, the
Comicall Passages of an Italian Bridewell, where the Scæne ends. Written by
Thomas Dekker
London
Printed by Elizabeth All-de for Nathaniel Butter 1630
84 p.
Preliminaries omitted

The honest whore, part ii.
Genre: Comedy.
Date first published: 1630.
Date first performed: 1604-1605 ?

encodingDesc.p: The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations. Lodovico Carolo Fontinell Astolfo Bercaldo Bryan Bellafront Hipolito Duke Orlando Friscobaldo Infælice Antonio Georgio Matheo Bots Candido Constable Master of Bridewell 1 Bride (wife to Candido) Mistress Horseleech Dorothea Target Penelope WhoreHound Catherina Bountinall Serving Man 1 Serving Man 2 Prentice 1 Guest 1 Luke Servant Vintner 1 Vintner 2 Constable Two or more speakers together

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by IDREF which point to the following.

div1.stage: Enter at one doore Beraldo, Carolo, Fontinell, Astolfo, with Seruingmen, or Pages attending on them; at another doore enter Lodouico, meeting them.

sp.speaker: Lodouico
sp.p: Good day, Gallants.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Good morrow, sweet Lodouico.

sp.speaker: Lodo.
sp.p: How dost thou Carolo.

sp.speaker: Carolo..
sp.p:
Faith, as Physicians do
in a Plague, see the World sick,
and am well myself.

sp.speaker: Fontinell..
sp.p: Here is a sweet morning, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
O, a morning to tempt Ioue from his Ningle Ganimed,
which is but to give Dairy Wenches green gowns as
they are going amilking; what, is thy Lord stirring yet?

sp.speaker: Astolfo.
sp.p: Yes, he will not be horsed this hour, sure.

sp.speaker: Bercaldo.
sp.p:
My Lady swears he shall, for she longs to be
at Court.

sp.speaker: Carolo.
sp.p:
O, we shall ride switch and spur, would we
were there once.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: How now, is thy Lord ready?

sp.speaker: Bryan
sp.p:
No so crees sa me, my Lady will have some little
Ting in her belly first.

sp.speaker: Caro.
sp.p: O, then they will to breakfast.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
Footman, does my Lord ride in the Coach with my
Lady, or on horseback?

sp.speaker: Bry.
sp.p:
No foot la, my Lady will have my Lord sheet with
her, my Lord will sheet in the one side, and my Lady sheet
in the other side.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
My Lady sheet in the other side: did you ever hear a
Rascal talk so like a Pagan? Is it not strange that a fellow
of his star, should be seen here so long in Italy, yet
speak so from a Christian?

div1.stage: Enter Anthonio, Georgio, a poore Scholler.

sp.speaker: Astol.
sp.p:
An Irishman in Italy! that so strange! why, the nation
have running heads.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
Nay Carolo, this is more strange, I have been in France,
there is few of them: Marry, England they count a warm
chimney corner, and there they swarm like Crickets to the
crevice of a Brew-house; but Sir, in England I have noted
one thing.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: What is that, what is that of England?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Marry this Sir, what is he yonder?

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: A poor fellow would speak with my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
In England, Sir, troth I ever laugh when I think
on it: to see a whole Nation should be marked in the forehead,
as a man may say, with one Iron: why Sir, there all Costermongers
are Irishmen.

sp.speaker: Caro.
sp.p:
O, that is to show their Antiquity, as coming
from Eve, who was an Apple-wife, and they take after the
Mother.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Good, good, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
Why then, should all your Chimney-sweepers likewise
be Irishmen? answer that now, come, your wit.

sp.speaker: Caro.
sp.p:
Faith, that is soon answered, for Saint Patricke you
know keeps Purgatory, he makes the fire, and his
Country-men could do nothing, if they cannot sweep the
Chimneys.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Good again.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
Then, Sir, have you many of them (like this fellow)
(especially those of his hair) Footmen to Noblemen and others,
and the Knaves are very faithful where they love, by
my faith very proper men many of them, and as active as
the clouds, whir, hah.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Are they so?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
And stout! exceeding stout; Why, I warrant, this
precious wild Villain, if he were put to it, would fight
more desperately than sixteen Dunkerkes.

sp.speaker: Asto.
sp.p: The women they say are very fair.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
No, no, our Country Bona Robes, O! are the sugariest
delicious Rogues.

sp.speaker: Asto.
sp.p: O, look, he has a feeling of them.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
Not I, I protest,there is a saying when they commend
Nations: It goes, the Irishman for his hand, Welshman
for a leg, the Englishman for a face, the Dutchman for
beard.

sp.speaker: Fron.
sp.p: I'faith, they may make swabbers of them.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: The Spaniards, let me see, for a little foot (I take it) the Frenchman, what a pox hath he? and so of the rest. Are they at breakfast yet? come walk.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: This Lodouico, is a notable tongued fellow.

sp.speaker: Fron.
sp.p: Discourses well.

sp.speaker: Berc.
sp.p: And a very honest Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Asto.
sp.p: O! he is well valued by my Lord.

sp.speaker: Fron.
sp.p: How now, how now, what is she?

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: Let us make towards her.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Will it be long, sir, ere my Lord come forth?

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: Would you speak with my Lord?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
How now, what is this, a Nurses Bill? hath any here
got thee with child, and now will not keep it?

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: No sir, my business is unto my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
He is about his own wife now, he will hardly dispatch
two causes in a morning.

sp.speaker: Asto.
sp.p:
No matter what he says, fair Lady, he is a Knight,
there is no hold to be taken at his words.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.p: My Lord will pass this way presently.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: A pretty plump Rogue.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: A good lusty bouncing baggage.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: Do you know her?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
A pox on her, I was sure her name was in my Table-book
once, I know not of what cut her die is now, but she
has been more common than Tobacco: this is she that had
the name of the Honest Whore.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Is this she?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
This is the Blackamoor that by washing was turned
white: this is the Birding Piece new scoured: this is she
that (if any of her religion can be saved) was saved by my
Lord Hipolito.

sp.speaker: Asto.
sp.p: She has been a goodly creature.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
She has been! that is the Epitaph of all Whores, I am
well acquainted with the poor Gentleman her Husband,
Lord! what fortunes that man has overreached? She knows
not me, yet I have been in her company, I scarce know her,
for the beauty of her cheek hath (like the Moon) suffered
strange Eclipses since I beheld it: but women are like Meddlers
(no sooner ripe but rotten.)
sp.l: A woman last was made, but is spent first,
Yet man is oft proved, in performance worst.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: My Lord is come.

div1.stage: Enter Hypolito, Infæliche, and two waiting women.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: We have wasted half this morning: morrow Lodouico.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Morrow Madam.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Let us away to Horse.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Aye, aye to Horse, to Horse.

sp.speaker: Bela.
sp.p:
I do beseech your Lordship, let your eye read
over this wretched Paper.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: I am in haste, pray the good woman take some apter time.

sp.speaker: Infæ..
sp.p: Good Woman do.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: O alas! it does concern a poor man's life.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p:
Life! sweet heart? Seat yourself, I will but read this
and come.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
What stockings have you put on this morning, Madam?
if they be not yellow, change them; that paper is a
Letter from some Wench to your Husband.

sp.speaker: Infæ..
sp.p: O sir, that cannot make me jealous.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Your business, sir, to me?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Yes my good Lord.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Presently sir; are you Matheo's wife.

sp.speaker: Bela.
sp.p: That most unfortunate woman.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: I am sorry these storms are fall on him, I love Matheo.
And any good shall do him, he and I.
Have sealed two bonds of friendship, which are strong
In me, however Fortune does him wrong;
He speaks here he is condemned. Is it so?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Too true.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p:
What was he whom he killed? O, his name is here;
old Iacomo, son to the Florentine Iacomo, a dog, that to
meet profit, would to the very eyelids wade in blood of his
own children. Tell Matheo, the Duke my father hardly
shall deny his signed pardon, it was fair fight, yes if rumours
tongue go true, so writes he here.
sp.l: Tomorrow morning I return from Court,
Pray be you here then. I will have done sir straight:
But in troth say, are you Matheo's wife?
You have forgot me.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: No, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Your Turner,
That made you smooth to run an even bias,
You know I loved you when your very soul
Was full of discord: art not a good wench still?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p:
Umph, when I had lost my way to heaven, you showed it:
I was new born that day.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
'sfoot, my Lord, your Lady asks if you have not left
your Wench yet? When you get in once, you never have
done: come, come, come, pay your old score, and send her
packing, come.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Ride softly on before, I will overtake you.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
Your Lady swears she will have no riding on before,
without ye.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Prithee good Lodouico.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: My Lord pray hasten.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p:
I come: tomorrow let me see you, fare you well:
commend me to Matheo: pray one word more: Does not
your father live about the Court?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I think he does, but such rude spots of shame Stick on my cheek, that he scarce knows my name.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Orlando Friscabaldo, Is it not?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Yes my Lord.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: What does he for you?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: All he should: when Children
From duty start, Parents from love may swarve.
He nothing does: for nothing I deserve.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p:
Shall I join him unto you, and restore you
to wonted grace?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: It is impossible.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: It shall be put to trial: fare you well:
The face I would not look on! sure then it was rare,
When in despite of grief, it is still thus fair.
Now, sir, your business with me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
I am bold to express my love and duty to your
Lordship in these few leaves.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: A Book!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Yes my good Lord.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Are you a Scholar?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, a poor one.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Sir, you honour me.
Kings may be Scholars Patrons, but faith tell me,
To how many hands besides hath this bird flown,
How many partners share with me?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Not one in troth, not one: your name I held more dear,
I am not (my Lord) of that low Character.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Your name I pray?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Antonio Georgio.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Of Millan?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Yes my Lord.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: I will borrow leave
To read you over, and then we will talk: till then
Drink up this gold, good wits should love good wine,
This of your loves, the earnest that of mine.
How now, sir, where is your Lady, not gone yet?

sp.speaker: Bryan.
sp.p:
I fart the Lady is run away from thee, a mighty
deal of ground, she sent me back for thine own sweet
face, I pray thee come my Lord away, wilt thou go now?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Is the Coach gone?
Saddle my Horse the sorrel.

sp.speaker: Bryan.
sp.p:
A pox on the Horses nose, he is a lousy rascally
fellow, when I came to gird his belly, his scurvy guts rumbled,
the Horse farted in my face, and thou knowest, an Irishman
cannot abide a fart, but I have saddled the Hobby-horse,
the fine Hobby is ready, I pray thee my good sweet Lord, wilt
thou go now, and I will run to the Devil before thee?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Well, sir, I pray let us see you Master Scholar.

sp.speaker: Bry.
sp.p: Come I pray thee, wilt come sweet face? Go.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Gods son, Gentlemen, what do we forget?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
Are not we all enjoined as this day, Thursday is it
not? Aye as that day to be at the Linen-drapers house at dinner?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Seignior Candido, the patient man.

sp.speaker: Asto.
sp.p: Afore Ioue, true, upon this day he is married.

sp.speaker: Berc.
sp.p:
I wonder, that being so stung with a Wasp before,
he dares venture again to come about the eaves amongst
Bees.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
O it is rare sucking a sweet Honeycomb; pray
Heaven his old wife be buried deep enough, that she rise
not up to call for her dance, the poor Fiddlers Instruments
would crack for it, she would tickle them: at any hand let us try
what mettle is in his new Bride, if there be none, we will put
in some; troth it is a very noble Citizen, I pity he should
marry again, I will walk along, for it is a good old fellow.

sp.speaker: Caro.
sp.p:
I warrant, the Wives of Millan would give any
fellow twenty thousand Ducats, that could but have the
face to beg of the Duke, that all the Citizens in Millan
might be bound to the peace of patience, as the Linen-draper
is.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
O fie upon it, it would undo all us that are Courtiers,
we should have no whore with the wenches then.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: My Lord is come.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: How now, what news?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: None.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Your Lady is with the Duke her Father.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: And we will to them both presently, who is that?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Seignior Friscabaldo.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p:
Friscabaldo, O! pray call him, and leave me, we
two have business.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Ho Seignior! Seignior Friscabaldo. The Lord Hipollito.

sp.speaker: Orla.
sp.p:
My Noble Lord: my Lord Hipollito! the Dukes
Son! his brave Daughters brave Husband! how does
your honoured Lordship! does your Nobility remember so
poor a Gentleman as Seignior Orlando Friscabaldo! old mad
Orlando!

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p:
O sir, our friends they ought to be unto us as our Jewels,
as dearly valued, being locked up, and unseen, as when
we wear them in our hands. I see, Friscabaldo, age hath not
command of your blood, for all Times sickle has gone over
you, you are Orlando still.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
Why my Lord, are not the fields mown and cut
down, and stripped bare, and yet wear they not pied coats
again? though my head be like a Leek, white: may not my
heart be like the blade, green?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Scarce can I read the Stories on your brow,
Which age hath writ there, you look youthful still.

sp.speaker: Orla.
sp.l: I eat Snakes, my Lord, I eat Snakes.
sp.p:
My heart shall never have a wrinkle in it, so long as I can cry
Hem with a clear voice.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: You are the happier man, sir.

sp.speaker: Orla.
sp.p:
Happy man! I will give you (my Lord) the true picture
of a happy man; I was turning leaves over this morning,
and found it, an excellent Italian Painter drew it, If I have
it in the right colours, I will bestow it on your Lordship.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: I stay for it.

sp.speaker: Orla.
sp.l: He that makes gold his wife, but not his whore,
He that at noonday walks by a prison door,
He that in the Sun is neither beam nor mote,
He that is not mad after a Petticoat,
He for whom poor men's curses dig no grave,
He that is neither Lords nor Lawyers slave,
He that makes This his Sea, and That his Shore,
He that in his Coffin is richer than before,
He that counts Youth his Sword, and Age his Staff,
He whose right hand carves his own Epitaph,
He that upon his death-bead is a Swan,
And Dead, no Crow, he is a happy man.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: It is very well, I thank you for this Picture.

sp.speaker: Orla.
sp.p:
After this Picture (my Lord) do I strive to have
my face drawn:
sp.l: For I am not covetous,
Am not in debt,
Sit neither at the Dukes side,
Nor lie at his feet.
Wenching and I have done, no man I wrong,
No man I fear, no man I see;
I take heed how far I walk, because I know yonder is my home.
I would not die like, a rich man, to carry nothing away save a winding sheet:
But like a good man, to leave Orlando behind me.
I sowed leaves in my Youth, and I reap now Books in my Age.
I fill this hand, and empty this, and when the bell shall toll for me, if I prove a Swan and go singing to my nest, why so?
If a Crow will throw me out for carrion, and pick out mine eyes,
May not old Friscabaldo (my Lord) be merry now! ha?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: You may, would I were partner in your mirth.

sp.speaker: Orla.
sp.l: I have a little,
Have all things;
I have nothing; I have no wife, I have no child, have no chick, and why should not I be in my Iocundare?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Is your wife then departed?

sp.speaker: Orla.
sp.l: She is an old dweller in those high Countries,
Yet not from me,
sp.p:
Here, she is here: but before me, when a Knave and Quean
are married, they commonly walk like Sergeants together:
but a good couple are seldom parted.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: You had a Daughter too sir, had you not?

sp.speaker: Orla.
sp.p:
O my Lord! this old Tree had one Branch, (and
but one Branch growing out of it) It was young, it was
fair, it was straight; I pruned it daily, dressed it carefully,
kept it from the wind, helped it to the Sun, yet for all
my skill in planting, it grew crooked, it bore Crabs; I
hewed it down,
sp.l: What is become of it, I neither know, nor care.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p:
Then can I tell you what is become of it;
That Branch is withered.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: So it was long ago.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Her name I think was Bellafront, she is dead.

sp.speaker: Orlando.
sp.p: Ha? dead?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p:
Yes, what of her was left, not worth the keeping,
Even in my sight was thrown into a Grave.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
Dead aye my last and best peace go with her, I see
death is a good trencherman, he can eat course homely meat,
as well as the daintiest.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Why, Friscabaldo, was she homely?

sp.speaker: Orla.
sp.p:
O my Lord! a Strumpet is one of the Devils Vines;
all the sins like so many Poles are stuck upright out of
hell, to be her props, that she may spread upon them. And
when she is ripe, every Slave has a pull at her, then must she
be pressed. The young beautiful Grape sets the teeth of Lust
on edge, yet to taste that licorice Wine, is to drink a man's
own damnation. Is she dead?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: She is turned to earth.

sp.speaker: Orla.
sp.p:
Would she were turned to heaven; Um, is she dead!
I am glad the world has lost one of his Idols; no Whoremonger
will at midnight beat at the doors; In her grave
sleep all my shame, and her own; and all my sorrows,
and all her sins.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: I am glad you are wax, not marble; you are made
Of man's best temper, there are now good hopes
That all these heaps of
Ice about your heart,
By which a fathers love was frozen up,
Are thawed in these sweet showers fetched from your eyes,
We are never like Angels till our passion dies,
She is not dead, but lives under worse fate,
I think she is poor, and more to clip her wings,
Her Husband at this hour lies in the Jail,
For killing of a man, to save his blood,
Join all your force with mine: mine shall be shown,
The getting of his life preserves your own.

sp.speaker: Orla.
sp.l: In my daughter you will say! does she live then?
sp.p:
I am sorry I wasted tears upon a Harlot, but the best is I
have a handkercher to drink them up, soap can wash them
all out again.
Is she poor?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Trust me, I think she is.

sp.speaker: Orla.
sp.p:
Then she is a right Strumpet; I never knew any of
their trade rich two years together; Sieves can hold no
water, nor Harlots hoard up money; they have many vents,
too many sluices to let it out; Taverns, Tailors, Bawds,
Panders, Fiddlers, Swaggerers, Fools and Knaves, do all
wait upon a common Harlots trencher: she is the Galleypot
to which these Drones fly: not for love to the pot, but
for the sweet sucket within it, her money, her money.

sp.speaker: Hip.
Orla.
sp.p: Not seventeen Summers.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Is your hate so old?

sp.speaker: Orla.
sp.p:
Older; it has a white head, and shall never die till
she be buried, Her wrongs shall be my bedfellow.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Work yet his life, since in it lives her fame.

sp.speaker: Orla.
sp.p:
No, let him hang, and half her infamy departs out
of the world: I hate him for her; he taught her first to taste
poison; I hate her for herself, because she refused my
Physic.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Nay but Friscabaldo.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: I detest her, I defy both, she is not mine, she is.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Hear her but speak.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
I love no Mermaids, I will not be caught with a quail
pipe.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: You are now beyond all reason.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
I am then a Beast Sir, I had rather be a beast, and not
dishonour my creation, than be a doting father, and like Time,
be the destruction of mine own brood.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Is it dotage to relieve your child being poor?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Is it fit for an old man to keep a whore?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: It is charity too.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: It is foolery; relieve her!
Were her cold limbs stretched out upon a Bier,
I would not sell this dirt under my nails
To buy her an hours breath, nor give this hair,
Unless it were to choke her.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Fare you well, for I will trouble you no more.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
And fare you well sir, go thy ways, we have few
Lords of thy making, that love wenches for their honesty;
Alas my Girl! art thou poor? poverty dwells next door
to despair,there is but a wall between them; despair is
one of hells Catch-poles; and lest that Devil arrest her, I will
to her, yet she shall not know me; she shall drink of my
wealth, as beggars do of running water, freely, yet never
know from what Fountains head it flows. Shall a silly
bird pick her own breast to nourish her young ones, and
can a father see his child starve? That were hard; The Pelican
does it, and shall not I. Yes, I will victual the Camp
for her, but it shall be by some stratagem; that knave there
her husband will be hanged I fear, I will keep his neck out
of the noose if I can, he shall not know how.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: How now knaves, whither wander you?
To seek your Worship.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
Stay, which of you has my purse, what money
have you about you?
Some fifteen or sixteen pounds, sir.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
Give it me, I think I have some gold about me; yes,
it is well; leave my Lodging at Court, and get you home.
Come sir, though I never turned any man out of doors, yet I will
be so bold as to pull your Coat over your ears.
What do you mean to do sir?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
Hold thy tongue knave, take thou my Cloak, I hope I
play not the paltry Merchant in this bartering; bid the
Steward of my house, sleep with open eyes in my absence,
and to look to all things, whatsoever I command by Letters
to be done by you, see it done. So, does it sit well?
As if it were made for your Worship.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
You proud Varlets, you need not be ashamed to
wear blue, when your Master is one of your fellows; away,
do not see me.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: This is excellent.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
I should put on a worse suite too; perhaps I will.
My Vizard is on, now to this mask. Say I should shave off
this Honour of an old man, or tie it up shorter; Well, I will
spoil a good face for once. My beard being off, how should
I look? even like
sp.l: A Winter Cuckoo, or unfeathered Owl;
Yet better lose this hair, than lose her soul.

div1.stage: Enter Candido, Lodouico, and Carolo. Lodouico other Guests, and Bride wish Prentises.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p:
O Gentlemen, so late, you are very welcome, pray
sit down.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Carolo, didst ever see such a nest of Caps?

sp.speaker: Asto.
sp.l: It is a most civil and most comely sight.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: What does he in the middle look like?

sp.speaker: Asto.
sp.p:
Troth like a spire steeple in a Country Village
overpeering so many thatched houses.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
It is rather a long pike staff against so many bucklers
without pikes; they sit for all the world like a pair of
Organs, and he is the tall great roaring pipe in the middest.

sp.speaker: Asto.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: What is that you laugh at, Seigniors?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Troth shall I tell you, and aloud I will tell it,
We laugh to see (yet laugh we not in scorn)
Amongst so many Caps that long Hat worn.

sp.speaker: Lodo..
sp.p:
Mine is as tall a felt as any is this day in Millan, and
therefore I love it, for the block was cleft out for my head,
and fits me to a hair.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Indeed you are good observers, it shows strange.
But Gentlemen, I pray neither contemn,
Nor yet deride a civil ornament;
I could build so much in the round Caps praise,
That love this high roof, I this flat would raise.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Prithee sweet Bridegroom do it.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: So all these guests will pardon me, I will do it.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: With all our hearts.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Thus then in the Caps honour,
To every Sex and state, both Nature, Time,
The Countries laws, yea and the very Clime
Do allot distinct habits, the spruce Courtier
Jets up and down in silk: the Warrior
Marches in buff, the Clown plods on in gray:
But for these upper garments thus I say,
The Sea-man has his Cap, pared without brim,
The Gallants head is feathered, that fits him;
The Soldier has his Murrain, women have Tires;
Beasts have their head-pieces, and men have theirs.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Proceed.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Each degree has his fashion, it is fit then,
One should be laid by for the Citizen,
And that is the Cap which you see swells not hie,
For Caps are Emblems of humility;
It is a Citizens badge, and first was worn
By the Romans; for when any Bondmans turn
Came to be made a Freeman: thus it was said,
He to the Cap was called; that is, was made
Of Rome a Freeman, but was first close shorn,
And so a Citizens hair is still short worn.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: That close shaving made Barbers a Company,
And now every Citizen uses it.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Of Geometric figures the most rare,
And perfectest are the Circle and the square,
The City and the School much build upon
These figures, for both love proportion.
The City Cap is round, the Scholars square,
To show that Government and learning are
The perfectest limbs in the body of a State:
For without them, all is disproportionate.
If the Cap had no honour, this might rear it,
The Reverend Fathers of the Law do wear it.
It is light for Summer, and in cold it sits
Close to the scull, a warm house for the wits;
It shows the whole face boldly, it is not made
As if a man to look on it were afraid,
Nor like a Drapers shop with broad dark shed,
For he is no Citizen that hides his head.
Flat Caps as proper are to City Gowns,
As to Armours Helmets, or to Kings their Crowns.
Let then the City Cap by none be scorned,
Since with it Princes heads have been adorned.
If more the round Caps honour you would know,
How would this long Gown with this steeple show?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha: most vile, most ugly.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: Pray Seignior pardon me, it was done in jest.

sp.speaker: Bride.
sp.p: A cup of claret wine there.
Wine: yes forsooth, wine for the Bride.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: You have well set out the Cap, sir.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Nay, that is flat.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: A health.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Since his Cap is round, that
Shall go round. Be bare,
For in the Caps praise all of you have share.

div1.stage: The Bride hits the Prentice on the lips.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: The Bride is at cuffs.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p:
O, peace I pray thee, thus far off I stand, I spied the
error of my servants, she called for Claret, and you filled out
Sack; that cup give me, it is for an old man's back, and
not for hers. Indeed it was but mistaken, ask all these
else.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: No faith, it was but mistaken.
Nay, she took it right enough.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Good Luke reach her that glass of Claret.
Here, Mistress Bride, pledge me there.

sp.speaker: Bride.
sp.p: Now I will none.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: How now?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Look what your Mistress ails.

Nothing, sir, but about filling a wrong glass, a scurvy
tricke.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p:
I pray you hold your tongue, my servant there tells
me she is not well.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Step to her, step to her.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
A word with you: do ye hear? This wench (your
new wife) will take you down in your wedding shoes,
unless you hang her up in her wedding garters.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: How, hang her in her garters?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
Will you be a tame Pigeon still? shall your back
be like a Tortoise shell, to let Carts go over it, yet not to
break? This She-cat will have more lives than your last
Puss had, and will scratch worse, and mouse you worse:
look to it.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: What would you have me do, sir?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
What would I have you do? Swear, swagger,
brawl, fling; for fighting it is no matter, we have had knocking
Pusses enough already; you know, that a woman was made of
the rib of a man, and that rib was crooked. The Moral of
which is, that a man must from his beginning be crooked
to his wife; be you like an Orange to her, let her cut you never
so fair, be you sour as vinegar; will you be ruled by me?

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: In anything that is civil, honest, and just.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Have you ever a Prentices suite will sit me?

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: I have the very same which myself wore.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
I will send my man for it within this half hour, and
within this two hours I will be your Prentice: the Hen shall
not overcrow the Cock, I will sharpen your spurs.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: It will be but some jest, sir.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Only a jest: farewell, come Carolo.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: We will take our leaves, Sir, too.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p:
Pray conceit not ill of my wives sudden rising.
This young Knight, Sir Lodouico, is deep seen in Physic,
and he tells me, the disease called the Mother, hangs on my
wife, it is a vehement heaving and beating of the Stomach,
and that swelling did with the pain thereof cramp up her
arm, that hit his lips, and brake the glass: no harm, it was
no harm.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: No, Seignior, none at all.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: The straightest arrow may fly wide by chance.
But come, we will close this brawl up in some dance.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p:
O my sweet Husband, wert thou in thy grave, and
art alive again? O welcome, welcome.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
Dost know me? my cloak prithee lay it up. Yes
faith, my winding sheet was taken out of Lavender, to be
stuck with Rosemary, I lacked but the knot here, or here;
yet if I had had it, I should have made a wry mouth at the
world like a Plays: but sweetest villain, I am here now, and
I will talk with thee soon.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: And glad am I thou art here.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
Did these heels caper in shackles? Ah my little
plump rogue, I will bear up for all this, and fly hie. Catzo
Catzo.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Matheo?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
What sayst, what sayst? O brave fresh air, a pox
on these Grates and jingling of Keys, and rattling of Iron.
I will bear up, I will fly hie wench, hang Toss.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Matheo, prithee make thy prison thy glass,
And in it view the wrinkles, and the scars,
By which thou wert disfigured, viewing them, mend them.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
I will go visit all the mad rogues now, and the good
roaring boys.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Thou dost not hear me?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Yes faith do I.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p:
Thou hast been in the hands of misery, and taken strong
Physic, prithee now be sound.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
Yes. 'sfoot, I wonder how the inside of a Tavern
looks now. O when shall I bizle, bizle?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p:
Nay see, thou art thirsty still for poison, come, I will
not have thee swagger.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Honest Apes face.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: It is that sharpened an axe to cut thy throat.
Good Love, I would not have thee sell thy substance
And time (worth all) in those damned shops of Hell;
Those Dicing houses, that stand never well,
But when they stand most ill, that four-squared sin
Has almost lodged us in the beggars Inn.
Besides (to speak which even my soul does grieve)
A sort of Ravens have hung upon thy sleeve,
And fed upon thee: good Mat. (if you please) so base as
Scorn to spread wing amongst these;
By them thy fame is speckled, yet it shows
Clear amongst them; so Crows are fair with Crows.
Custom in sin, gives sin a lovely die.
Blackness in Mores is no deformity.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
Bellafront, Bellafront, I protest to thee, I swear, as I
hope my soul, I will turn over a new leafe, the prison I
confess has bit me, the best man that sails in such a Ship,
may be lousy.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: One knocks at door.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
I will be the Porter: they shall see, a Jail cannot hold
a brave spirit, I will fly hie.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: How wild is his behaviour! O, I fear
He is spoiled by prison, he is half damned comes there,
But I must sit all storms: when a full sail his
Fortunes spread, he loved me: being now poor,
I will beg for him, and no wife can do more.

div1.stage: Enter Matheo, and Orlando like a Seruingman.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Come in pray, would you speak with me, sir?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Is your name Seignior Matheo?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: My name is Seignior Matheo.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Is this Gentlewoman your wife, sir?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: This Gentlewoman is my wife, sir.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
The Destinies spin a strong and even thread of both
your loves: the Mothers own face, I have not forgot that, I am
an old man, sir, and am troubled with a whoreson salt rheum,
that I cannot hold my water. Gentlewoman, the last man I
served was your Father.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: My Father? any tongue that sounds his name,
Speaks Music to me: welcome good old man.
How does my father? lives he? has he health?
How does my father? I so much do shame him,
So much do wound him, that I scarce dare name him.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: I can speak no more.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: How now old Lad, what dost cry?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
The rheum still, sir, nothing else; I should be well
seasoned, for mine eyes lie in brine: look you, sir, I have a
suite to you.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.p: What is it my little white pate?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Troth, sir, I have a mind to serve your Worship.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
To serve me? Troth, my friend, my fortunes are, as
a man may say --

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
Nay look you, sir, I know when all sins are old
in us, and go upon Crutches, that Covetousness does but
then lie in her Cradle; It is not so with me. Lechery loves
to dwell in the fairest lodging, and Covetousness in the
oldest buildings, that are ready to fall: but my white head,
sir, is no Inn for such a gossip. If a Serving man at my years
be not stored with biscuit enough, that has sailed about the
world to serve him the voyage out of his life, and to bring
him East-home; Ill pity but all his days should be fasting
days: I care not so much for wages, for I have scraped a
handful of gold together; I have a little money, sir, which
I would put into your Worships hands, not so much to
make it more.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
No, no, you say well, thou sayst well; but I must
tell you: How much is the money, sayst thou?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: About twenty pound, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
Twenty pound? Let me see: that shall bring thee in,
after ten per centum, per annum.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
No, no, no, sir, no; I cannot abide to have money engender:
fie upon this silver Lechery, fie; if I may have
meat to my mouth, and rags to my back, and a flock-bed
to snort upon, when I die, the longer liver take all.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
A good old Boy, i'faith, if thou servest me, thou shalt
eat as I eat, drink as I drink, lie as I lie, and ride as I ride.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: That is if you have money to hire horses.

What dost thou think on it? This good old
Lad here shall serve me.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Alas, Matheo, wilt thou load a back
That is already broke?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
Peace, pox on you, peace,there is a tricke in it, I
fly hie, it shall be so, Front. as I tell you: give me thy hand,
thou shalt serve me i'faith: welcome: as for your money --

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Nay, look you sir, I have it here.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
Pesh, keep it thyself, man, and then thou art sure it is
safe.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
Safe! if it were ten thousand Ducats, your Worship
should be my cash-keeper; I have heard what your Worship
is, an excellent dunghill Cock, to scatter all abroad:
but I will venture twenty pounds on his head.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
And didst thou serve my Worshipful Father-in-law,
Seignior Orlando Friscabaldo, that mad man once?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: I served him so long, till he turned me out of doors.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: It is a notable Chuff, I have not seen him many a day.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
No matter if you never see him: it is an arrant Grandy,
a Churl, and as damned a cut-throat.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Thou villain, curb thy tongue, thou art a Iudas, To sell thy Masters name to slander thus.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Away Ass, he speaks but truth, thy father is a --

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
And an old knave,there is more deceit in him than
in sixteen Apothecaries: it is a Devil, thou mayst beg, starve,
hang, damn; does he send thee so much as a chief?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Or so much as a Gammon of Bacon, He will give it his Dogs first.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: A Jail, a Jail.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: A Jew, a Jew, sir.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: A Dog.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: An English Mastiff, sir.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Pox rot out his old stinking garbage.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Art not ashamed to strike an absent man thus?
Art not ashamed to let this vild Dog bark,
And bite my Father thus? I will not endure it;
Out of my doors, base slave.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
Your doors! a vengeance? I shall live to cut that old
rogues throat, for all you take his part thus.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: He shall live to see thee hanged first.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
Gods son my Lord, your Lordship is most welcome,
I am proud of this, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Was bold to see you.
Is that your wife?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: I will borrow her lip.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: With all my heart, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Who is this, I pray sir?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: My Lord Hipollito: what is thy name?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Pacheco.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
Pacheco, fine name; Thou seest, Pacheco, I keep
company with no Scoundrels, nor base fellows.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Came not my Footman to you?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Yes my Lord.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: I sent by him a Diamond and a Letter, Did you receive them?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Yes my Lord, I did.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Read you the letter?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Over and over it is read.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: And faith your answer?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Now the time is not fit,
You see, my Husband is here.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: I will now then leave you,
And choose mine hour; but ere I part away,
Hark, you remember I must have no nay.
Matheo, I will leave you.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: A glass of wine.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Not now, I will visit you at other times.
You are come off well then?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
Excellent well, I thank your Lordship: I owe you
my life, my Lord; and will pay my best blood in any service
of yours.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p:
I will take no such dear payment, hark you Matheo,
I know, the prison is a gulf, if money run low with you,
my purse is yours: call for it.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
Faith my Lord, I thank my stars, they send me
down some; I cannot sink, so long as these bladders hold.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: I will not see your fortunes ebb, pray try.
To starve in full barnes were fond modesty.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Open the door, sirrah.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p:
Drink this, and anon I pray thee give thy Mistress
this.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: O Noble Spirit, if no worse guests here dwell,
My blue coat sits on my old shoulders well.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
The only royal fellow, he is bounteous as the Indies,
what is that he said to thee, Bellafront?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Nothing.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: I prithee good Girl?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Why I tell you nothing.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
Nothing? it is well: tricks, that I must be beholden
to a scald hot-livered goatish Gallant, to stand with my
cap in my hand, and vail bonnet, when I have spread as lofty
sails as himself, would I had been hanged. Nothing? Pacheco,
brush my cloak.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Where is it, sir?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Come, we will fly hie.
Nothing? there is a whore still in thine eye.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: My twenty pounds flies high, O wretched woman,
This varlet is able to make Lucrece common.
sp.p:
How now Mistress? has my Master died you into this sad
colour?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p:
Fellow, be gone I pray thee; if thy tongue itch after
talk so much, seek out thy Master, thou art a fit instrument
for him.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: 'swounds, I hope he will not play upon me?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Play on thee? no, you two will fly together,
Because you are roving arrows of one feather.
Would thou wouldst leave my house, thou never shalt
Please, me weave thy nets never so hie,
Thou shalt be but a spider in mine eye.
Thou art rank with poison, poison tempered well,
Is food for health; but thy black tongue doth swell
With venom, to hurt him that gave thee bread,
To wrong men absent, is to spurn the dead.
And so didst thou thy Master, and my Father.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
You have small reason to take his part; for I have
heard him say five hundred times, you were as arrant a
whore as ever stiffened tiffany neckcloths in water-starch
upon a Saturday in the afternoon.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Let him say worse, when for the earths offence
Hot vengeance through the marble clouds is driven,
Is it fit earth shoot again those darts at heaven?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
And so if your Father call you whore, you will not call
him old knave: Friscabaldo, she carries thy mind up and
down; she is thine own flesh, blood, and bone; troth Mistress,
to tell you true, the fireworks that ran from me upon
lines against my good old Master, your father, were but to
try how my young Master your Husband loved such squibs:
but it is well known, I love your father as myself; I will ride
for him at mid-night, run for you by Owl-light; I will die
for him, drudge for you; I will fly low, and I will fly hie (as
my Master says) to do you good, if you will forgive me.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I am not made of marble: I forgive thee.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
Nay, if you were made of marble, a good Stone-cutter
might cut you: I hope the twenty pound I delivered
to my Master, is in a sure hand.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: In a sure hand I warrant thee for spending.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
I see my young Master is a madcap, and a bonus socius,
I love him well, Mistress: yet as well as I love him, I will not
play the knave with you; look you, I could cheat you of
this purse full of money; but I, am an old Lad, and I scorn
to coney-catch: yet I have been Dog at a Cony in my time.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: A purse, where hadst it?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
The Gentleman that went away, whispered in mine
ear, and charged me to give it you.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: The Lord Hipollito?

sp.speaker: Orla.
sp.p: Yes, if he be a Lord, he gave it me.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: It is all gold.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
It is like so: it may be, he thinks you want money,
and therefore bestows his alms bravely, like a Lord.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: He thinks a silver net can catch the poor,
Here is bait to choake a Nun, and turn her whore.
Wilt thou be honest to me?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
As your nails to your fingers, which I think never
deceived you.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Thou to this Lord shalt go, commend me to him,
And tell him this, the Town has held out long,
Because (within) it was rather true, than strong.
To sell it now were base; Say it is no hold
Built of weak stuff, to be blown up with gold.
He shall believe thee by this token, or this; if not, by this.

sp.speaker: Orla.
sp.p: Is this all?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: This is all.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Mine own Girl still.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: A Star may shoot, not fall.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
A Star? nay, thou art more than the moon, for
thou hast neither changing quarters, nor a man standing in
thy circle with a bush of thorns. Is it possible the Lord
Hipollito, whose face is as civil as the outside of a Dedicatory
Book, should be a Muttonmonger? A poor man has
but one Ewe, and this Grandy Sheep-biter leaves whole
Flocks of fat Weathers (whom he may knock down)
to devour this. I will trust neither Lord nor Butcher with
quick flesh for this tricke; the Cuckoo I see now sings all
the year, though every man cannot hear him, but I will
spoil his notes; can neither Love-letters, nor the Devils
common Pick-locks (Gold) nor Precious Stones make my
Girl draw up her Percullis: hold out still, wench.
sp.l: All are not Bawds (I see now) that keep doors,
Nor all good wenches that are marked for Whores.

div1.stage: Enter Candido, Lodouico like a Prentice.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
Come, come, come, what do ye lack, sir? what
do ye lack, sir? what is it ye lack, sir? is not my Worship
well suited? did you ever see a Gentleman better disguised?

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: Never, believe me, Seignior.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
Yes: but when he has been drunk, there be Prentices
would make mad Gallants, for they would spend all, and
drink, and whore, and so forth; and I see we Gallants could
make mad Prentices. How does thy wife like me? Nay, I
must not be so saucy, then I spoil all: pray you how does
my Mistress like me?

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: Well: for she takes you for a very simple fellow.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
And they that are taken for such, are commonly
the arrantest knaves: but to our Comedy, come.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: I shall not act it, chide you say, and fret, And grow impatient: I shall never do it.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
'sblood, cannot you do as all the world does?
counterfeit.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p:
Were I a Painter, that should live by drawing nothing
but Pictures of an angry man, I should not earn my
colours; I cannot do it.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
Remember you are a Linen Draper, and that if you
give your wife a yard, she will take an ell: give her not therefore
a quarter of your yard, not a nail.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p:
Say I should turn to Ice, and nip her love now it is
but in the blood.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Well, say she is nipped.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: It will so overchange her heart with grief,
That like a Cannon, when her sighs go off,
She in her duty either will recoil,
Or break in pieces and so die: her death,
By my unkindness might be counted murther.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
Die? never, never; I do not bid you beat her, nor
give her black eyes, nor pinch her sides: but cross her
humours. Are not Bakers arms the scales of Justice? yet
is not their bread light? and may not you I pray bridle her
with a sharpe bit, yet ride her gently?

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p:
Well, I will try your pills, do you your faithful
service, and be ready still at a pinch to help me in this
part, or else I shall be out clean.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Come, come, I will prompt you.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: I will call her forth now, shall I?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Do, do, bravely.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: Luke, I pray bid your Mistress to come hither.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Luke, I pray bid your Mistress to come hither.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: Sirrah, bid my wife come to me: why, when?

sp.speaker: Luke
sp.p: Presently, sir, she comes.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: La you,there is the echo, she comes.

sp.speaker: Bride.
sp.p: What is your pleasure with me?

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Marry wife,
I have intent, and (you see) this stripling here,
He bears good will and liking to my trade,
And means to deal in Linen.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
Yes indeed, sir, I would deal in Linen, if my Mistress
like me so well as I like her?

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p:
I hope to find him honest, pray good wife look
that his bed and chamber be made ready.

sp.speaker: Bride.
sp.p:
You are best to let him hire me for his maid?
I look to his bed? look to it yourself.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: Even so I swear to you a great oath.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Swear, cry S'wounds.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: I will not, go to wife, I will not.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: That your great oath?

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: Swallow these gudgeons.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Well said.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Then fast, then you may choose.
You know at Table
What tricks you played, swaggered, broke glasses! Fie,
Fie, fie, fie: and now before my Prentice here
You make an ass of me; thou, (what shall I call thee?)

sp.speaker: Bride.
sp.p: Even what you will.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Call her arrant whore.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p:
O fie, by no means, then she will call me Cuckold,
sirra, go look to the shop: how does this show?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
Excellent well, I will go look to the shop, sir. Fine
Cambrics, Lawns, what do you lack.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: A cursed Cows milk I have drunk once before,
And it was so rank in taste, I will drink no more.
Wife, I will tame you.

sp.speaker: Bride.
sp.l: You may, sir, if you can,
But at a wrestling I have seen a fellow
Limbed like an Ox, thrown by a little man.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: And so you will throw me. Reach me (Knaves) a yard.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: A Yard for my Master.

sp.speaker: 1. Prent.
sp.p: My Master is grown valiant.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: I will teach you fencing tricks.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Rare, rare; a prize.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: What will you do, sir?

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: Marry, my good Prentice, nothing but breathe my wife.

sp.speaker: Bride.
sp.p: Breathe me with your yard?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: No, he will but measure you out, forsooth.

sp.speaker: Bride.
sp.l: Since you will needs fence, handle your weapon well,
For if you take a yard, I will take an ell.
Reach me an ell.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: An ell for my Mistress.
sp.p:
Keep the laws of the Noble Science, sir, and measure weapons
with her; your yard is a plain Heathenish weapon; it is too
short, she may give you a handful, and yet you will not reach her.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Yet I have the longer arm, come fall to it roundly,
And spare not me (wife) for I will lay it on soundly.
If over husbands their wives will needs be Masters,
We men will have a law to win it at wasters

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: It is for the breeches, is it not?

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: For the breeches.

sp.speaker: Bride.
sp.p: Husband I am for you, I will not strike in jest.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: Nor I.

sp.speaker: Bride.
sp.p: But will you sign to one request?

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: What is that?

sp.speaker: Bride.
sp.p: Let me give the first blow.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: The first blow, wife, shall I? Prompt?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Let her have it.
If she strike hard, into her, and break her pate.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: A bargain. Strike.

sp.speaker: Bride.
sp.l: Then guard you from this blow,
For I play all at legs, but it is thus low.
Behold, I am such a cunning Fencer grown,
I keep my ground, yet down I will be thrown
With the least blow you give me, I disdain
The wife that is her husbands Sovereign.
She that upon your pillow first did rest,
They say, the breeches wore, which I detest.
The tax which she imposed upon you, I abate you,
If me you make your Master, I shall hate you.
The world shall judge who offers fairest play;
You win the breeches, but I win the day.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Thou winnest the day indeed, give me thy hand,
I will challenge thee no more: my patient breast
Played thus the Rebel, only for a jest:
Here is the rank rider that breaks Colts, it is he
Can tame the mad folks, and cursed wives.

sp.speaker: Bride.
sp.p: Who, your man?

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: My man? my Master, though his head be bare,
But he is so courteous, he will put off his hair.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
Nay, if your service be so hot, a man cannot keep
his hair on, I will serve you no longer.

sp.speaker: Bride.
sp.p: Is this your Schoolmaster?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
Yes faith, wench, I taught him to take thee down:
I hope thou canst take him down without teaching; you
have got the conquest, and you both are friends.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: Bear witness else.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: My Prenticeship then ends.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: For the good service you to me have done,
I give you all your years.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I thank you Master.
I will kiss my Mistress now, that she may say,
My man was bound, and free all in one day.

sp.speaker: Infæ..
sp.p: From whom sayst thou?

sp.speaker: Orla.
sp.p: From a poor Gentlewoman, Madam, whom I serve.

sp.speaker: Infæ..
sp.p: And what is your business?

sp.speaker: Orla.
sp.p:
This, Madam: my poor Mistress has a waste piece
of ground, which is her own by inheritance, and left to
her by her mother; There is a Lord now that goes about,
not to take it clean from her, but to enclose it to himself,
and to join it to a piece of his Lordships.

sp.speaker: Infæ..
sp.p: What would she have me do in this?

sp.speaker: Orla.
sp.p:
No more, Madam, but what one woman should
do for another in such a case. My Honourable Lord, your
Husband would do anything in her behalf, but she had
rather put herself into your hands, because you (a woman)
may do more with the Duke your Father.

sp.speaker: Infæ..
sp.p: Where lies this Land?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
Within a stones cast of this place; my Mistress, I think,
would be content to let him enjoy it after her decease, if
that would serve his turn, so my Master would yield too:
but she cannot abide to hear that the Lord should meddle
with it in her life time.

sp.speaker: Infæ..
sp.p:
Is she then married? why stirs not her Husband
in it?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
Her Husband stirs in it under hand: but because
the other is a great rich man, my Master is loath to be seen
in it too much.

sp.speaker: Infæ..
sp.l: Let her in writing draw the cause at large:
And I will move the Duke.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
It is set down, Madam, here in black and white
already: work it so, Madam, that she may keep her own
without disturbance, grievance, molestation, or meddling of
any other; and she bestows this purse of gold on your Ladyship.

sp.speaker: Infæ..
sp.l: Old man, I will plead for her, but take no fees:
Give Lawyers them, I swim not in that flood,
I will touch no gold, till I have done her good.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
I would all Proctors Clerks were of your mind,
I should law more amongst them than I do then; here, Madam,
is the survey, not only of the Manor itself, but of
the Grange house, with every Meadow pasture, Ploughland,
Cony-borough, Fish-pond, hedge, ditch, and bush
that stands in it.

sp.speaker: Infæ..
sp.p:
My Husbands name, and hand and seal at arms
to a Love-letter? Where hadst thou this writing?

sp.speaker: Orla.
sp.p:
From the foresaid party, Madam, that would keep
the foresaid Land out of the foresaid Lords fingers.

sp.speaker: Infæ..
sp.p: My Lord turned Ranger now?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
You are a good Huntress, Lady, you have found your
Game already; your Lord would fain be a Ranger, but my
Mistress requests you to let him run a course in your own
Park, if you will not do it for love, then do it for money; she
has no white money, but there is gold, or else she prays you
to ring him by this token, and so you shall be sure his nose
will not be rooting other men's pastures.

sp.speaker: Infæ..
sp.l: This very purse was woven with mine own hands,
This Diamond on that very night, when he
Untied my Virgin girdle, gave I him:
And must a common Harlot share in mine?
Old man, to quit thy pains, take thou the gold.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Not I, Madam, old Serving-men want no money.

sp.speaker: Infæ..
sp.l: Cupid himself was sure his Secretary,
These lines are even the Arrows Love let flies,
The very Ink dropped out of Uenus eyes.

sp.speaker: Orla.
sp.p:
I do not think, Madam, but he fetched off some
Poet or other for those lines, for they are parlous Hawks
to fly at wenches.

sp.speaker: Infæ..
sp.p: Here is honeyed poison, to me he never thus writ, But Lust can set a double edge on wit.

sp.speaker: Orla.
sp.p:
Nay, that is true, Madam, a wench will whet any
thing, if it be not too dull.

sp.speaker: Infæ..
sp.l: Oaths, promises, preferments, Jewels, gold,
What snares should break, if all these cannot hold?
What creature is thy Mistress?

sp.p:
One of those creatures that are contrary to man;
a woman.

sp.speaker: Infæ..
sp.p: What manner of woman?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
A little tiny woman, lower than your Ladyship by
head and shoulders, but
as mad a wench as ever unlaced a
petticoat: these things should I indeed have delivered to my
Lord your Husband.

sp.speaker: Infæ..
sp.p:
They are delivered better: Why should she send
back these things?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Ware, ware,there is knavery.

sp.speaker: Infæ..
sp.l: Strumpets like cheating gamesters will not win
At first: these are but baits to draw him in.
How might I learn his hunting hours?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
The Irish Footman can tell you all his hunting
hours, the Park he hunts in, the Do he would strike, that
Irish Shackatory beats the bush for him, and knows all;
he brought that Letter, and that Ring; he is the Carrier.

sp.speaker: Infæ..
sp.p:
Knowest thou what other gifts have past between
them?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Little Saint Patricke knows all.

sp.speaker: Infæ..
sp.p: Him I will examine presently.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Not whilst I am here, sweet Madam.

sp.speaker: Infæ..
sp.p: Be gone then, and what lies in me command.

sp.speaker: Infæ..
sp.p:
Come hither sirrah, how much cost those Satins, and
cloth of Silver, which my husband sent by you to a low
Gentlewoman yonder?

sp.speaker: Bry.
sp.p:
What Satins? what Silvers, what low Gentlefolks?
thou pratest thou knowest not what, yfaat la.

sp.speaker: Infæ..
sp.p: She there, to whom you carried letters.

sp.speaker: Bry.
sp.p:
By this hand and body thou sayst true, if I did so, O
how? I know not a letter of the Book yfaat la.

sp.speaker: Infæ..
sp.p:
Did your Lord never send you with a Ring, sir, set
with a Diamond?

sp.speaker: Bry.
sp.p:
Never, sa crees sa me, never; he may run at a thousand
rings yfaat, and I never hold his stirrup, till he leap into
the saddle. By Saint Patricke, Madam, I never touch my Lords
Diamond, nor ever had to do, yfaat la, with any of his precious
stones.

sp.speaker: Infæ..
sp.p: Are you so close, you Bawd, you pandering slave?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: How now? why Infælice? what is your quarrel?

sp.speaker: Infæ..
sp.p: Out of my sight, base varlet, get thee gone.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Away you rogue.

sp.speaker: Bry.
sp.p: Slawne loot, fare thee well, fare thee well.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: What, grown a fighter? prithee what is the matter?

sp.speaker: Infæ..
sp.p:
If you will needs know, it was about the clock: how
works the day, my Lord, (pray) by your watch?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p:
Lest you cuff me, I will tell you presently: I am
near two.

sp.speaker: Infæ..
sp.p: How, two? I am scarce at one.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: One of us then goes false.

sp.speaker: Infæ..
sp.l: Then sure it is you,
Mine goes by heavens Dial, (the Sun) and it goes true.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: I think (indeed) mine runs somewhat too fast.

sp.speaker: Infæ..
sp.p: Set it to mine (at one) then.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: One? it is past:
It is past one by the Sun.

sp.speaker: Infæ..
sp.l: Faith then belike,
Neither your clock nor mine does truly strike,
And since it is uncertain which goes true,
Better be false at one, than false at two.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: You are very pleasant, Madam.

sp.speaker: Infæ..
sp.p: Yet not merry.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Why Infælice, what should make you sad?

sp.speaker: Infæ..
sp.l: Nothing my Lord, but my false watch, pray tell me,
You see, my clock, or yours is out of frame,
Must we upon the Workman lay the blame,
Or on yourselves that keep them?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Faith on both.
He may by knavery spoil them, we by sloth,
But why talk you all riddle thus? I read
Strange Comments in those margins of your looks:
Your cheeks of late are (like bad printed Books)
So dimly charactered, I scarce can spell,
One line of love in them. Sure all is not well.

sp.speaker: Infæ..
sp.l: All is not well indeed, my dearest Lord,
Look up thy gates of hearing, that no sound
Of what I speak may enter.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: What means this?

sp.speaker: Infæ..
sp.l: Or if my own tongue must myself betray,
Count it a dream, or turn thine eyes away,
And think me not thy wife.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Why do you kneel?

sp.speaker: Infæ..
sp.p:
Earth is sins cushion: when the sick soul feels
herself growing poor, then she turns beggar, cries and
kneels for help; Hipollito (for husband I dare not call
thee) I have stolen that Jewel of my chaste honour (which
was only thine) and given it to a slave.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Hah?

sp.speaker: Infæ..
sp.l: On thy pillow adultery and lust have slept, thy Groom
Hath climbed the unlawful tree, and plucked the sweets,
A villain hath usurped a husbands sheets.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: 'sdeath, who, (a Cuckold) who?

sp.speaker: Infæ..
sp.p: This Irish Footman.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p:
Worse than damnation, a wild Kern, a Frog, a
Dog: whom I will scarce spurn. Longed you for Shamrock?
were it my fathers father (heart) I will kill him, although I
take him on his death-bed gasping betwixt heaven and hell;
a shag-haired Cur? Bold Strumpet, why hangest thou on me?
thinkst I will be a Bawd to a Whore, because she is Noble?

sp.speaker: Infæ..
sp.l: I beg but this,
Set not my shame out to the worlds broad eye,
Yet let thy vengeance (like my fault) soar high,
So it be in darkened clouds.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Darkened! my horns
Cannot be darkened, nor shall my revenge.
A Harlot to my slave? the act is base,
Common, but foul, so shall thy disgrace:
Could not I feed your appetite? O women
You were created Angels; pure and fair;
But since the first fell, tempting Devils you are,
You should be men's bliss, but you prove their rods.
Were there no women, men might live like gods:
You have been too much down already, rise,
Get from my sight, and henceforth shun my bed,
I will with no Strumpets breath be poisoned.
As for your Irish Leprechaun, that spirit
Whom by preposterous charms thy lust hath raised
In a wrong Circle, him I will damn more black
Than any Tyrants soul.

sp.speaker: Infæ..
sp.p: Hippolito?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p:
Tell me, didst thou bait Hawks to draw him to
thee, or did he bewitch thee?

sp.speaker: Infæ..
sp.p: The slave did woo me.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p:
Two whoos in that Screech-owls language? O
who would trust your cork-heeled sex? I think to sate
your lust, you would love a Horse, a Bear, a croaking Toad,
so your hot itching veins might have their bound, then the
wild Irish Dart was thrown. Come, how? the manner of
this fight.

sp.speaker: Infæ..
sp.l: It was thus, he gave me this battery first. O I
Mistake, believe me, all this in beaten gold:
Yet I held out, but at length this was charmed.
What? change your Diamond wench, the act is base,
Common but foul, so shall not your disgrace:
Could not I feed your appetite? O Men,
You were created Angels, pure and fair,
But since the first fell, worse than Devils you are.
You should our shields be, but you prove our rods.
Were there no Men, Women might live like gods.
Guilty my Lord?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Yes, guilty my good Lady.

sp.speaker: Infæ..
sp.l: Nay, you may laugh, but henceforth shun my bed,
With no whores leavings I will be poisoned.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Over-reached so finely? It is the very Diamond
And Letter which I sent: this villainy
Some Spider closely weaves, whose poisoned bulk
I must let forth. Who is there without?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: My Lord calls.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Send me the Footman.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Call the Footman to my Lord, Bryan, Bryan.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: It can be no man else, that Irish Iudas,
Bred in a Country where no venom prospers,
But in the Nations blood hath thus betrayed me.
Slave, get you from your service.

sp.speaker: Bry.
sp.p: What meanest thou by this now?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Question me not, nor tempt my fury, villain,
Couldst thou turn all the Mountains in the land,
To hills of gold, and to give me; here thou stayest not.

sp.speaker: Bry.
sp.p: I what, I care not.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Prate not, but get thee gone, I shall send else.

sp.speaker: Bry.
sp.p:
Aye, do prithee, I had rather have thee make a scabbard
of my guts, and let out all the Irish puddings in my poor
belly, than to be a false knave to thee I what, I will never see
thine own sweet face more. fare thee well,
fare thee well, I will go steal Cows again in Ireland.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: He is damned that raised this whirlwind, which hath blown
Into her eyes this jealousy: yet I will on,
I will on, stood armed Devils staring in my face,
To be pursued in flight, quickens the race,
Shall my blood streams by a wives lust be bard?
Fond woman, no: Iron grows by strokes more hard,
Lawless desires are seas scorning all bounds,
Or sulphur which being rammed up, more confounds,
Struggling with mad men, madness nothing tames,
Winds wrestling with great fires, incense the flames.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: How now, what ails your Master?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
Has taken a younger brothers purge, forsooth, and
that works with him.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Where is his Cloak and Rapier?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
He has given up his Cloak, and his Rapier is bound
to the Peace: If you look a little higher, you may see that
another hath entered into hatband for him too. Six and
four have put him into this sweat.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Where is all his money?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
It is put over by exchange: his doublet was going to
be translated, but for me: if any man would have lent but
half a ducat on his beard, the hair of it had stuffed a pair
of breeches by this time; I had but one poor penny, and
that I was glad to niggle out, and buy a holly-wand to grace
him through the street. As hap was, his boots were on, and
then I dustied, to make people think he had been riding,
and I had run by him.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: O me, how does my sweet Matheo?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
O Rogue, of what devilish stuff are these Dice
made of? of the parings of the Devils corns of his toes,
that they run thus damnably.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I prithee vex not.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
If any handy-crafts man was ever suffered to keep
shop in hell, it will be a Dice-maker; he is able to undo
more souls than the Devil; I played with mine own Dice,
yet lost. Have you any money?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Alas I have none.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
Must have money, must have some, must have a
Cloak, and Rapier, and things: will you go set your limetwigs,
and get me some birds, some money?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: What limetwigs should I set?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
You will not then? Must have cash and pictures:
do ye hear, (frailty)
shall I walk in a Plimouth Cloak,
(that is to say) like a rogue, in my hose and doublet, and a
crabtree cudgel in my hand, and you swim in your Satins?
must have money, come.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Is it bed-time, Master, that you undo my Mistress?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Undo me? Yes, yes, at these riflings
I have been too often.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Help to flea, Pacheco.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Fleaing call you it?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: I will pawn you by the Lord, to your very eyebrows.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: With all my heart, since heaven will have me poor,
As good be drowned at sea, as drowned at shore.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
Why hear you, sir? i'faith do not make away her
Gown.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
O it is Summer, it is Summer; your only fashion
for a woman now, is to be light, to be light.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
Why, pray sir, employ some of that money you have
of mine.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
Thine? I will starve first, I will beg first; when I touch a
penny of that, let these fingers ends rot.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
So they may, for that is past touching. I saw my
twenty pounds fly hie.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
Knowest thou never a damned Broker about the
City?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Damned Broker? yes, five hundred.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
The Gown stood me in above twenty Ducats,
borrow ten of it, cannot live without silver.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: I will make what I can of it, sir, I will be your Broker,
But not your damned broker: O thou scurvy knave,
What makes a wife turn whore, but such a slave?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
How now little chick, what ailest, weeping
For a handful of Tailors shreds? pox on them, are there
not silks enough at Mercers?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I care not for gay feathers, I.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: What dost care for then? why dost grieve?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Why do I grieve? A thousand sorrows strike
At one poor heart, and yet it lives. Matheo,
Thou art a Gamester, prithee throw at all,
Set all upon one cast, we kneel and pray,
And struggle for life, yet must be cast away.
Meet misery quickly then, split all, sell all,
And when thou hast sold all, spend it, but I beseech thee
Build not thy mind on me to coin thee more,
To get it wouldst thou have me play the whore?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: It was your profession before I married you.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Um? it was indeed: if all men should be branded
For sins long since laid up, who could be saved?
The Quarter day is at hand, how will you do
To pay the Rent, Matheo?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
Why? do as all of our occupation do against
Quarter days; break up house, remove, shift your lodgings,
pox on your Quarters.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Where is this Gallant?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
Seignior Lodouico? how does my little Mirror of
Knight-hood? this is kindly done i'faith: welcome by my
troth.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
And how dost, frolic? Save you fair Lady. Thou
lookest smug and bravely, Noble Mat.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Drink and feed, laugh and lie warm.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Is this thy wife?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
A poor Gentlewoman, sir, whom I make use of
a-nights.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Pay custom to your lips, sweet Lady.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
Borrow some shells of him, some wine, sweet
heart.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: I will send for it then i'faith.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: You send for it? Some wine I prithee.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I have no money.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: 'sblood, nor I: What wine love you, Seignior?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
Here, or I will not stay, I protest; trouble the Gentlewoman
too much?
And what news flies abroad, Matheo?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
Troth, none. O Seignior, we have been merry in our
days.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: And no doubt shall again.
The Divine powers never shoot Darts at men
Mortal, to kill them.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: You say true.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Why should we grieve at want?
Say the world made thee her Minion, that
Thy head lay in her lap, and that she danced thee
On her wanton knee, she could but give thee a whole
World: that is all, and that all is nothing; the worlds
Greatest part cannot fill up one corner of thy heart.
Say, the three corners were all filled, alas!
Of what art thou possessed, a thin blown glass:
Such as by Boys is puffed into the air.
Were twenty Kingdoms thine, thou wouldst live in care:
Thou couldst not sleep the better, nor live longer,
Nor merrier be, nor healthfuller, nor stronger.
If then thou wantest, thus make that want thy pleasure,
No man wants all things, nor has all in measure.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
I am the most wretched fellow: sure some left-handed
Priest christened me, I am so unlucky: I am never
out of one puddle or another, still falling.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Fill out wine to my little finger.
With my heart i'faith.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Thanks, good Matheo.
To your own sweet self.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
All the Brokers hearts, sir, are made of flint, I can
with all my knocking, strike but six sparks of fire out of
them, here is six ducats, if you will take them.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
Give me them: an evil conscience gnaw them all,
moths, and plagues hang upon their lousy wardrobes.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Is this your man, Matheo? An old Serving-man.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: You may give me the other half too, sir:
That is the Beggar.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: What hast there, gold?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
A sort of Rascals are in my debt, (God knows
what) and they feed me with bits, with crumbs, a pox
choke them.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: A word, Matheo: be not angry with me,
Believe it that I know the touch of time,
And can part copper (though it be gilded over)
From the true gold: the sails which thou dost spread,
Would show well, if they were not borrowed.
The sound of thy low fortunes drew me hither,
I give myself unto thee, prithee use me,
I will bestow on you a suite of Satin,
And all things else to fit a Gentleman,
Because I love you.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Thanks, good Noble Knight.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Call on me when you please,
Till then farewell.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Hast angled? hast cut up this fresh Salmon?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Wouldst have me be so base?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: It is base to steal, it is base to be a whore:
Thou wilt be more base, I will make thee keep a door.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
I hope he will not sneak away with all the money,
will he?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Thou seest he does.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
Nay then it is well. I set my brains upon an upright
Last; though my wits be old, yet they are like a withered pippin,
wholesome. Look you, Mistress, I told him I had but six
ducats of the (Knave) Broker, but I had eight, and kept
these two for you.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Thou shouldst have given him all.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: What, to fly hie?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Like waves, my misery drives on misery.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
Sell his wives clothes from her back? does any.
Poulterers wife pull chickens alive? He Riots all abroad,
wants all at home; he Dices, whores, swaggers, swears,
cheats, borrows, pawns: I will give him hook and line,
a little more for all this.
sp.l: Yet sure in the end he will delude all my hopes,
And show me a French tricke danced on the ropes.

div1.stage:
Enter at one doore Lodouico and Carolo; at another Bots,
and Mistress Horsleach; Candido and his wife
appeare in the Shop.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Hist, hist, Lieutenant Bots, how dost, man?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Whither are you ambling, Madam Horsleach?

sp.speaker: Hors.
sp.p: About worldly profit, sir: how do your Worships?

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.p:
We want tools, Gentlemen, to furnish the trade:
they wear out day and night, they wear out till no mettle
be left in their back; we hear of two or three new
Wenches are come up with a Carrier, and your old
Goshawk here is flying at them.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: And faith, what flesh have you at home?

sp.speaker: Hors.
sp.p:
Ordinary Dishes, by my troth, sweet men,there is
few good in the City; I am as well furnished as any, and though
I say it, as well customed.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.p:
We have meats of all sorts of dressing; we have
stewed meat for your Frenchmen, pretty light picking meat
for your Italian, and that which is rotten roasted, for Don
Spaniardo.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: A pox on it.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.p:
We have Poulterers ware your sweet bloods, as
Dove, Chicken, Duck, Teal, Woodcock, and so forth: and
Butchers meat for the Citizen: yet Muttons fall very bad
this year.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
Stay, is not that my patient Linen Draper yonder,
and my fine young smug Mistress, his wife?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p:
Sirrah Grandam, I will give thee for thy fee twenty
crowns, if thou canst but procure me the wearing of yon
velvet cap.

sp.speaker: Hors.
sp.p:
You would wear another thing besides the cap. You are a
Wag.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.p:
Twenty crowns? we will share, and I will be your pulley
to draw her on.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Do it presently; we will have some sport.

sp.speaker: Hors.
sp.p:
Wheel you about, sweet men: do you see, I will cheapen
wares of the man, whilst Bots is doing with his wife.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
To it: if we come into the shop to do you grace,
we will call you Madam.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.p:
Pox on your old face, give it the badge of all scurvy
faces, a Masque.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p:
What is it you lack, Gentlewoman? Cambric or
Lawns, or fine Hollands? Pray-draw near, I can sell you a
penny-worth.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.p: Some Cambric for my old Lady.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: Cambric? you shall, the purest thread in Millan.

sp.speaker: Lod. and Car.
sp.p: Save you, Seignior Candido.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: How does my Noble Master? how my fair Mistress?

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p:
My Worshipful good Servant, view it well, for it is
both fine and even.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p:
Cry you mercy, Madam, though masked, I thought it
should be you by your man. Pray Seignior, show her the best,
for she commonly deals for good ware.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: Then this shall fit her, this is for your Ladyship.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.p:
A word, I pray, there is a waiting Gentlewoman of
my Ladies: her name is Ruyna, says she is your Kinswoman,
and that you should be one of her Aunts.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: One of her Aunts? troth sir, I know her not.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.p:
If it please you to bestow the poor labour of your
legs at any time, I will be your convoy thither?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p:
I am a Snail, sir, seldom leave my house, if it please
her to visit me, she shall be welcome.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.p:
Do you hear? the naked troth is: my Lady hath
a young Knight, her son, who loves you, you are made, if you
lay hold upon it: this Jewel he sends you.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p:
Sir, I return his love and Jewel with scorn; let
go my hand, or I shall call my husband. You are an arrant
Knave.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: What, will she do?

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.p:
Do? they shall all do if Bots sets upon them once,
she was as if she had professed the trade, squeamish at first, at
last I showed her this Jewel, said, a Knight sent it her.

sp.speaker: Lod.
