sp.p: Is it gold, and right stones?

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.p: Copper, Copper, I go a-fishing with these baits.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
She nibbled, but would not swallow the hook because
the Cunger-head her husband was by: but she bids the
Gentleman name any afternoon, and she will meet him at her
Garden house, which I know.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Is this no lie now?

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.p: Damn me if --

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: O prithee stay there.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.p: The twenty crowns, sir.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
Before he has his work done? but on my Knightly
word, he shall pay it thee.

div1.stage: Enter Astolpho, Beraldo, Fontinell, and the Irish Footman.

sp.speaker: Asto.
sp.p:
I thought thou hadst been gone into thine own
Country.

sp.speaker: Bry.
sp.p: No what la, I cannot go this four or tree days.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p:
Look thee, yonder is the shop, and that is the man
himself.

sp.speaker: Fon.
sp.p:
Thou shalt but cheapen, and do as we told thee, to
put a jest upon him, to abuse his patience.

sp.speaker: Bry.
sp.p:
I what, I doubt my pate shall be knocked: but sa crees
sa me, for your shakes, I will run to any Linen Draper in
hell, come prithee.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Save you Gallants.

sp.speaker: Lod. and Car.
sp.p: O, well met!

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: You will give no more you say? I cannot take it.

sp.speaker: Hors.
sp.p: Truly I will give no more.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p:
It must not fetch it. What would you have, sweet
Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Asto.
sp.p: Nay, here is the Customer.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
The Garden-house you say? we will bolt out your
roguery.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p:
I will but lay these parcels by -- My men are all
at Custom-house unloading Wares, if Cambric you would
deal in,there is the best, all Millan cannot sample it.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
Do you hear? one. two. three. 'sfoot, there came in four.
Gallants, sure your wife is slipped up, and the fourth man I hold
my life, is grafting your Warden tree.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha: you Gentlemen are full of Jest.
If she be up, she is gone some wares to show,
I have above as good wares as below.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Have you so? nay then --

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: Now Gentlemen, is it Cambrics?

sp.speaker: Bry.
sp.p: I prithee now let me have the best wares.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: What is that he says, pray Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Marry he says we are like to have the best wares.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: The best wares? all are bad, yet wares do good,
And like to Surgeons, let sick Kingdoms blood.

sp.speaker: Bry.
sp.p:
What a Devil pratest thou so, a pox on thee, I prithee
let me see some Hollen, to make Linen shirts, for fear my
body be lousy.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: Indeed I understand no word he speaks.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p:
Marry, he says, that at the siege in Holland there was
much bawdry used among the Soldiers, though they were
lousy.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: It may be so, that is likely, true indeed,
In every garden, sir, does grow that weed.

sp.speaker: Bry.
sp.p:
Pox on the gardens, and the weeds, and the fools
cap there, and the clouts; hear? dost make a Hobby-horse
of me.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: O fie, he has torn the Cambric.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: It is no matter.

sp.speaker: Asto.
sp.p: It frets me to the soul.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: So dost not me.
My Customers do oft for remnants call,
These are two remnants now, no loss at all.
But let me tell you, were my Servants here,
It would have cost more. -- Thank you Gentlemen,
I use you well, pray know my shop again.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha; come, come, let us go, let us go.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: How am I suited, Front? am I not gallant, ha?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Yes, sir, you are suited well.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Exceeding passing well, and to the time.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: The Taylor has played his part with you.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
And I have played a Gentleman's part with my Taylor,
for I owe him for the making of it.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: And why did you so, sir?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
To keep the fashion; It is your only fashion now
of your best rank of Gallants, to make their Tailors wait
for their money, neither were it wisdom indeed to pay
them upon the first edition of a new suite: for commonly
the suite is owing for, when the linings are worn out, and
there is no reason then, that the Taylor should be paid before
the Mercer.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Is this the suite the Knight bestowed upon you?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
This is the suite, and I need not shame to wear it,
for better men than I would be glad to have suites bestowed
on them. It is a generous fellow, -- but -- pox on him -- we
whose Pericranions are the very Limbecks and Stillitories
of good wit, and fly hie, must drive liquor out of stale gaping
Oysters. Shallow Knight, poor Squire Tinacheo: I will
make a wild Catame of forty such: hang him, he is an Ass,
he is always sober.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: This is your fault to wound your friends still.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
No faith, Front, Lodouico is a noble Slauonian: it is
more rare to see him in a woman's company, than for a Spaniard
to go into England, and to challenge the English Fencers
there. -- One knocks, -- See -- La, fa, sol, la, fa, la,
rustle in Silks and Satins:there is music in this, and a
Taffeta Petticoat, it make both fly hie, -- Catzo.

div1.stage: Enter Bellafront, after her Orlando like himselfe, with foure men after him.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Matheo? it is my Father.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
Ha, Father? It is no matter, he finds no tattered
Prodigals here.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
Is not the door good enough to hold your blue
Coats? away, Knaves. Wear not your clothes thread-bare
at knees for me; beg Heavens blessing, (not mine.) O cry
your Worship mercy, sir, was somewhat bold to talk to this Gentlewoman, your wife here.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: A poor Gentlewoman, sir.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Stand not, sir, bare to me; I have read oft That Serpents who creep low, belch ranker poison Than winged Dragons do, that fly aloft.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: If it offend you, sir? it is for my pleasure.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Your pleasure be it, sir; um, is this your Palace?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Yes, and our Kingdom, for it is our content.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
It is a very poor Kingdom then; what, are all your
Subjects gone a-sheep-shearing? not a Maid? not a Man?
not so much as a Cat? you keep a good house belike, just
like one of your profession, every room with bare walls,
and a half-headed bed to vault upon (as all your bawdy-houses
are.) Pray who are your Upholsters? O, the Spiders.
I see, they bestow hangings upon you.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Bawdy-house? S'wounds sir --

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: O sweet Matheo, peace. Upon my knees
I do beseech you, sir, not to arraign me
For sins, which heaven, I hope, long since hath pardoned.
Those flames (like lightning flashes) are so spent,
The heat no more remains, than where ships went,
Or where birds cut the air, the print remains.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Pox on him, kneel to a Dog?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: She that is a Whore,
Lives gallant, fares well, is not (like me) poor,
I have now as small acquaintance with that sin,
As if I had never known it; that, never been.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
No acquaintance with it? what maintains thee
then? how dost live then? has thy husband any Lands? any
Rents coming in, any Stock going, any Ploughs jogging,
any Ships sailing? hast thou any Wares to turn, so much
as to get a single penny by? yes, thou hast Ware to sell,
Knaves are thy Chapmen, and thy Shop is Hell.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Do you hear, sir?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: So sir, I do hear, sir, more of you than you dream I do.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: You fly a little too hie, sir.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Why, sir, too hie?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
I have suffered your tongue, like a bard Cater tra, to
run all this while, and have not stopped it.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Well, sir, you talk like a Gamester.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
If you come to bark at her, because she is a poor
rogue; look you, here is a fine path, sir, and there, there the
door.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Matheo?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Your blue Coats stay for you, sir.
I love a good honest roaring Boy, and so --

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: That is the Devil.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
Sir, sir, I will have no Ioues in my house to thunder Avaunt:
she shall live and be maintained, when you, like a
keg of musty Sturgeon, shall stink. Where? in your Coffin.
How? be a musty fellow, and lousy.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
I know she shall be maintained, but how? she like a
Quean, thou like a Knave; she like a Whore, thou like a
Thief.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Thief? S'wounds Thief?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Good dearest Mat. -- Father.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
Pox on you both, I will not be braved: New Satin
scorns to be put down with bare bawdy Velvet. Thief?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
I Thief, thou art a Murtherer, a Cheater, a Whore-monger,
a Pot-hunter, a Borrower, a Beggar --

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Dear Father.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
An old Ass, a Dog, a Churl, a Chuff, an Usurer, a
Villain, a Moth, a mangy Mule, with an old velvet foot cloth
on his back, sir.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: O me!

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Varlet, for this I will hang thee.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Ha, ha, alas.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Thou keepest a man of mine here, under my nose.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Under thy beard.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
As arrant a smell-smock, for an old Mutton-monger,
as thyself.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: No, as yourself.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
As arrant a purse-take as ever cried, Stand, yet a
good fellow, I confess, and valiant, but he will bring thee to the
Gallows; you both have robbed of late two poor Country
Peddlers.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
How is this? how is this? dost thou fly hie? rob
Peddlers? bear witness Front, rob Peddlers? my man and I a
Thief?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: O, sir, no more.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
I Knave, two Peddlers, hue and cry is up, Warrants
are out, and I shall see thee climb a Ladder.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
And come down again as well as a Bricklayer, or
a Tyler. How the vengeance knows he this? If I be hanged,
I will tell the people I married old Friscabaldoes Daughter,
I will frisco you, and your old carcass.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
Tell what thou canst; if I stay here longer, I shall be
hanged too, for being in thy company; therefore, as I found
you, I leave you.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Kneel, and get money of him.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
A Knave and a Quean, a Thief and a Strumpet, a
couple of Beggars, a brace of Baggages.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
Hang upon him. Aye, aye, sir, fare you well; we are so:
follow close -- we are Beggars -- in Satin -- to him.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Is this your comfort, when so many years You have left me frozen to death?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Freeze still, starve still.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Yes, so I shall: I must: I must and will.
If as you say I am poor, relieve me then,
Let me not sell my body to base men.
You call me Strumpet, Heaven knows I am none:
Your cruelty may drive me to be one:
Let not that sin be yours, let not the shame
Of common Whore live longer than my name.
That cunning Bawd (Necessity) night and day
Plots to undo me; drive that Hag away,
Lest being at lowest ebb, as now I am,
I sink forever.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Lowest ebb, what ebb?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: So poor, that (though to tell it be my shame)
I am not worth a dish to hold my meat;
I am yet poorer, I want bread to eat.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: It is not seen by your cheeks.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
I think she has read an Homely to tickle to the old
rogue.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Want bread?there is Satin: bake that.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: 'sblood, make Pasties of my clothes?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: A fair new Cloak, stew that; an excellent gilt Rapier.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Will you eat that, sir?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: I could feast ten good fellows with those Hangers.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: The pox you shall.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: I shall not (till thou beggest,) think thou art poor;
And when thou beggest, I will feed thee at my door,
As I feed Dogs, (with bones) till then beg,
Borrow, pawn, steal, and hang, turn Bawd.
When thou art no Whore, my heart-strings sure
Would crack, were they strained more.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
This is your Father, your damned -- confusion
light upon all the generation of you; he can come bragging
hither with four white Herrings (at his tail) in blue
Coats without roes in their bellies, but I may starve ere he
give me so much as a cob.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: What tell you me of this? alas.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
Go trot after your Dad, do you capitulate, I will
pawn not for you, I will not steal to be hanged for such an
hypocritical close common Harlot: away, you Dog --
Brave i'faith! Uds foot, Give me some meat.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
Goodman slave, my man too, is galloped to the Devil
on the other side: Pacheco, I will check you. Is this your
Dads day? England (they say) is the only hell for Horses, and
only Paradise for Women: pray get you to that Paradise,
because you are called an Honest Whore; there they live none
but honest whores with a pox: Marry here in our City, all
our sex are but foot-cloth Nags: the Master no sooner lights,
but the man leaps into the saddle.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Will you sit down I pray, sir?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
I could tear (by the Lord) his flesh, and eat his
midriff in salt, as I eat this: -- must I choake -- my
Father Friscabaldo, I shall make a pitiful Hog-louse of you
Orlando, if you fall once into my fingers -- Here is the savourest
meat: I have got a stomach with chafing. What Rogue
should tell him of those two Peddlers? A plague choake him,
and gnaw him to the bare bones: come fill.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p:
Thou sweatest with very anger, good sweet, vex not,
alas. it is no fault of mine.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
Where didst buy this Mutton? I never felt better
ribs.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: A neighbour sent it me.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
Hah, neighbour? foh, my mouth stinks, you whore,
do you beg victuals for me? Is this Satin doublet to be
bombasted with broken meat?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: What will you do, sir?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Beat out the brains of a beggarly --

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
Beat out an Asses head of your own; away, Mistress.
'swounds, do but touch one hair of her, and I will so quilt
your cap with old Iron, that your coxcomb shall ache the
worse these seven years for it: Does she look like a roasted
Rabbit, that you must have the head for the brains?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
Ha, ha: Go out of my doors, you Rogue, away,
four marks trudge.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
Four marks? no, sir, my twenty pound that you have
made fly hie, and I am gone.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
Must I be fed with chippings? you are best get a clapdish,
and say you are Proctor to some Spittle-house. Where
hast thou been, Pacheco? come hither my little Turkey-cock.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: I cannot abide, sir, to see a woman wronged, not I.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Sirrah, here was my Father-in-law today.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Pish, then you are full of Crowns.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
Hang him, he would have thrust crowns upon me, to
have fallen in again, but I scorn cast-clothes, or any man's
gold.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: But mine: how did he brooke that (sir?)

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
O: swore like a dozen of drunken Tinkers; at last
growing foul in words, he and four of his men drew upon
me, sir.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: In your house? would I had been by.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
I made no more ado, but fell to my old lock, and
so thrashed my blue Coats, and old crabtree-face my father-in-law,
and then walked like a Lion in my grate.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: O Noble Master!

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
Sirrah, he could tell me of the robbing the two
Peddlers, and that warrants are out for us both.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Good, sir, I like not those crackers.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Crackhalter, wilt set thy foot to mine?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: How, sir? at drinking.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
We will pull that old Crow my Father: rob thy Master.
I know the house, thou the servants: the purchase is
rich, the plot to get it easy, the Dog will not part from a
bone.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
Pluck it out of his throat then: I will snarl for one, if
this can bite.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
Say no more, say no more, old cole, meet me anon at
the sign of the Shipwreck.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: And dost hear, man? -- the Shipwreck.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Thou art at the Shipwreck now, and like a swimmer
Bold (but unexpert) with those waves dost play,
Whose dalliance (whorelike) is to cast thee away.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: And here is another Vessel, (better fraught,
But as ill manned) her sinking will be wrought,
If rescue come not: like a Man of war
I will therefore bravely out: somewhat I will do,
And either save them both, or perish too.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: It is my fate to be bewitched by those eyes.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Fate? your folly.
Why should my face thus mad you? alas, those colours
Are wound up long ago, which beauty spread,
The flowers that once grew here, are withered.
You turned my black soul white, made it look new,
And should I sin, it never should be with you.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Your hand, I will offer you fair play: When first
We met in the Lists together, you remember
You were a common Rebel; with one parley
I won you to come in.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: You did.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: I will try.
If now I can beat down this Chastity
With the same Ordnance; will you yield this Fort,
If with the power of Argument now (as then)
I get of you the conquest: as before
I turned you honest, now to turn you whore,
By force of strong persuasion?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: If you can,
I yield.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: The allarm is struck up: I am your man.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: A woman gives defiance.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Sit.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Begin:
It is a brave battle to encounter sin.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: You men that are to fight in the same war,
To which I am pressed, and plead at the same bar,
To win a woman, if you would have me speed,
Send all your wishes.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: No doubt you are heard, proceed.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: To be a Harlot, that you stand upon,
The very name is a charm to make you one.
Harlot was a Dame of so divine
And ravishing touch, that she was Concubine
To an English King: her sweet bewitching eye
Did the Kings heart-strings in such love-knots tie,
That even the coyest was proud when she could hear
Men say, Behold; another Harlot there;
And after her all women that were fair
Were Harlots called, as to this day some are:
Besides her dalliance, she so well does mix,
That she is in Latin called the Meretrix.
Thus for the name; for the profession, this,
Who lives in bondage, lives laced, the chief bliss
This world below can yield, is liberty:
And who (than whores) with looser wings dare fly?
As Iunoes proud bird spreads the fairest tail,
So does a Strumpet hoist the loftiest sail.
She is no man's slave; (men are her slaves) her eye
Moves not on wheels screwed up with Jealousy.
She (Horsed, or Coached) does merry journeys make,
Free as the Sun in his gilt Zodiac:
As bravely does she shine, as fast she is driven,
But stays not long in any house of Heaven:
But shifts from Sign, to Sign, her amorous prizes
More rich being when she is down, than when she rises.
In brief, Gentlemen haunt them, Soldiers fight for them,
Few men but know them, few or none abhor them:
Thus (for sport sake) speak I, as to a woman,
Whom (as the worst ground) I would turn to common:
But you I would enclose for mine own bed.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: So should a husband be dishonoured.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Dishonoured? not a whit: to fall to one
(Besides your husband) is to fall to none,
For one no number is.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Faith, should you take
One in your bed, would you that reckoning make?
It is time you sound retreat.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Say, have I won, Is the day ours?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: The battle is but half done,
None but yourself have yet sounded alarms,
Let us strike too, else you dishonour arms.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: If you can win the day,
The glory is yours.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: To prove a woman should not be a whore,
When she was made, she had one man, and no more,
Yet she was tied to laws then, for (even then)
It is said, she was not made for men, but man.
Anon, to increase earths brood, the law was varied,
Men should take many wives: and though they married
According to that Act, yet it is not known,
But that those wives were only tied to one.
New Parliaments were since: for now one woman
Is shared between three hundred, nay she is common;
Common? as spotted Leopards, whom for sport
Men hunt, to get the flesh, but care not for it.
So spread they Nets of gold, and tune their Calls,
To enchant silly women to take falls:
Swearing they are Angels, (which that they may win)
They will hire the Devil to come with false Dice in.
O Sirens subtle tunes! yourselves you flatter,
And our weak sex betray, so men love water;
It serves to wash their hands, but (being once foul)
The water down is poured, cast out of doors,
And even of such base use do men make whores.
A Harlot (like a Hen) more sweetness reaps,
To pick men one by one up, than in heaps:
Yet all feeds but confounding. Say you should taste me,
I serve but for the time, and when the day
Of war is done, am cashiered out of pay:
If like lame Soldiers I could beg, that is all,
And there is lusts Rendez-vous, an Hospital.
Who then would be a man's slave, a man's woman?
She is half starved the first day that feeds in Common.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: You should not feed so, but with me alone.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: If I drink poison by stealth, is it not all one?
Is it not rank poison still? with you alone!
Nay say you spied a Courtesan, whose soft side
To touch, you would sell your birth-right for one kiss,
Be racked, she is won, you are sated: what follows this?
O, then you curse that Bawd that tolled you in,
(The Night) you curse your lust, you loath the sin,
You loath her very sight, and ere the day
Arise, you rise glad when you are stolen away.
Even then when you are drunk with all her sweets,
There is no true pleasure in a Strumpets sheets.
Women, whom Lust so prostitutes to sale,
Like Dancers upon ropes; once seen, are stale.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: If all the threads of Harlots lives are spun,
So coarse as you would make them, tell me why
You so long loved the trade?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: If all the threads
Of Harlots lives be fine as you would make them,
Why do not you persuade your wife turn whore,
And all Dames else to fall before that sin?
Like an ill husband (though I knew the same,
To be my undoing) followed I that game.
O when the work of Lust had earned my bread,
To taste it, how I trembled, lest each bit,
Ere it went down, should choake me (chewing it?)
My bed seemed like a Cabin hung in Hell,
The Bawd Hells Porter, and the liquorish wine
The Pander fetched, was like an easy Fine,
For which, methought I leased away my soul,
And oftentimes (even in my quaffing bowl)
Thus said I to myself, I am a whore,
And have drunk down thus much confusion more.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: It is a common rule, and it is most true,
Two of one trade never love; no more do you.
Why are you sharpe against that you once professed?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Why dote you on that, which you did once detest?
I cannot (seeing she is woven of such bad stuff)
Set colours on a Harlot base enough.
Nothing did make me, when I loved them best,
To loath them more than this: when in the street
A fair young modest Damsel I did meet,
She seemed to all a Dove (when I passed by)
And I (to all) a Raven: every eye
That followed her, went with a bashful glance
At me, each bold and jeering countenance
Darted forth scorn: to her (as if she had been
Some Tower unvanquished) would they vail,
Against me swollen Rumour hoisted every sail.
She (crowned with reverend praises) passed by them,
I (though with face masked) could not scape the hem,
For (as if Heaven had set strange marks on Whores,
Because they should be pointing stocks to man)
Dressed up in civilest shape a Courtesan.
Let her walk Saint-like, noteless, and unknown,
Yet she is betrayed by some tricke of her own.
Were Harlots therefore wise, they would be sold dear:
For men account them good but for one year:
And then like Almanacs (whose dates are gone)
They are thrown by, and no more looked upon.
Who will therefore backward fall, who will launch forth
In Seas so foul, for ventures no more worth?
Lusts voyage hath (if not this course) this cross,
Buy never so cheap, your Ware comes home with loss.
What, shall I sound retreat? the battle is done:
Let the world judge which of us two have won.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: I!

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: You? Nay then as cowards do in fight,
What by blows cannot, shall be saved by flight.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Fly to earths fixed Centre: to the Caves
Of everlasting horror, I will pursue thee,
(Though laden with sins) even to Hells brazen doors.
Thus wisest men turn fools, doting on whores.

div1.stage: Enter the Duke, Lodouico, and Orlando: after them Infælice, Carolo, Astolfo, Beraldo, Fontinell.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
I beseech your Grace (though your eye be so piercing) as
under a poor blue Coat, to cull out an honest Father from
an old Serving-man: yet good my Lord discover not the plot
to any, but only this Gentleman that is now to be an
Actor in our ensuing Comedy.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Thou hast thy wish, Orlando, pass unknown,
Sforsa shall only go along with thee.
To see that Warrant served upon thy Son.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: To attach him upon felony, for two Peddlers: is it not so?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
Right, my Noble Knight: those Peddlers were two
Knaves of mine; he fleeced the men before, and now he purposes
to flea the Master. He will rob me, his teeth water to
be nibbling at my gold, but this shall hang him by the gills, till
I pull him on shore.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Away: ply you the business.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
Thanks to your Grace: but my good Lord, for my
Daughter.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: You know what I have said.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
And remember what I have sworn: She is more honest,
on my soul, than one of the Turkes Wenches, watched
by a hundred Eunuchs.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: So she had need, for the Turkes make them whores.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
He is a Turke that makes any woman a Whore, he is
no true Christian I am sure. I commit your Grace.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Infælice.

sp.speaker: Infæ..
sp.p: Here, sir.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Seignior Friscabaldo.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Frisking again, Pacheco?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
Uds son, Pacheco? we will have some sport with this
Warrant: it is to apprehend all suspected persons in the
house: Besides,there is one Bots a Pander, and one Madam
Horsleach a Bawd, that have abused my friend, those two
Coneys will we ferret into the purse-net.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
Let me alone for dabbing them on the neck: come,
come.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Do ye hear, Gallants? meet me anon at Matheos.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Enough.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: The old Fellow sings that note thou didst before,
Only his tunes are, that she is no Whore,
But that she sent his Letters and his gifts,
Out of a Noble Triumph over his Lust,
To show she trampled his Assaults in dust.

sp.speaker: Infæ,
sp.p: It is a good honest servant, that old man.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: I doubt no less.

sp.speaker: Infæ..
sp.l: And it may be my husband,
Because when once this woman was unmasked,
He leveled all her thoughts, and made them fit:
Now he would mar all again, to try his wit.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: It may be so too, for to turn a Harlot
Honest, it must be by strong Antidotes,
It is rare, as to see Panthers change their spots.
And when she is once a Star (fixed) and shines bright,
Though it were impiety then to dim her light,
Because we see such Tapers seldom burn.
Yet it is the pride and glory of some men,
To change her to a blazing Star again,
And it may be, Hipollito does no more.
It cannot be, but you are acquainted all
With that same madness of our Son-in-law,
That dotes so on a Courtesan.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: All the City thinks he is a Whoremonger.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: Yet I warrant, he will swear, no man marks him.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p:
It is like so, for when a man goes a wenching, is as if
he had a strong stinking breath, everyone smells him out,
yet he feels it not, though it be ranker than the sweat of sixteen
Bearwarders.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I doubt then you have all those stinking breaths,
You might be all smelt out.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p:
Troth my Lord, I think we are all as you have been in
your youth when you went a-Maying, we all love to hear
the Cuckoo sing upon other men's Trees.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: It is well yet you confess: but Girl, thy bed
Shall not be parted with a Courtesan -- it is strange,
No frown of mine, no frown of the poor Lady,
(My abused child, his wife) no care of fame,
Of Honour, Heaven or Hell, no not that name
Of Common Strumpet, can affright, or woo
Him to abandon her; the Harlot does undo him,
She has bewitched him, robbed him of his shape,
Turned him into a beast, his reason is lost,
You see he looks wild, does he not?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I have noted new Moons
In his face, my Lord, all full of change.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: He is no more like unto Hipollito,
Than dead men are to living -- never sleeps,
Or if he do, it is dreams; and in those dreams
His arms work, -- and then cries -- Sweet -- what is her
Name, what is the drabs name?

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: In troth, my Lord, I know not,
I know no drabs, not I.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: O, Bellafront!
And catching her fast, cries, My Bellafront.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p:
A drench that is able to kill a Horse, cannot kill this
disease of Smock-smelling, my Lord, if it have once eaten
deep.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I will try all Physic, and this Medicine first:
I have directed Warrants strong and peremptory
(To purge our City Millan, and to cure the outward
Parts, the Suburbs) for the attaching
Of all those women, who (like gold) want weight,
Cities (like Ships) should have no idle freight

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: No, my Lord, and light wenches are no idle freight,
But what is your Graces reach in this?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: This (Carolo.) If she whom my Son dotes on,
Be in that Master-book enrolled, he will shame
Ever to approach one of such noted name.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: But say she be not?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Yet on Harlots heads
New Laws shall fall so heavy, and such blows shall
Give to those that haunt them, that Hipollito
(If not for fear of Law) for love to her,
If he love truly, shall her bed forbear.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p:
Attach all the light heels in the City, and clap them up?
why, my Lord? you dive into a Well unsearchable: all the
Whores within the walls, and without the walls? I would not
be he should meddle with them for ten such Dukedoms;
the Army that you speak on, is able to fill all the prisons
within this City, and to leave not a drinking room in any
Tavern besides.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Those only shall be caught that are of note,
Harlots in each street flow:
The fish being thus in the net, ourself will sit,
And with eye most severe dispose of it. -- come, Girl.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Arraign the poor Whore.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: I will not miss that Sessions.

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.p: Nor I.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Nor I,
Though I hold up my hand there myself.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
Let who will come (my Noble Shauileir) I can but
play the kind Host, and bid them welcome.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
We will trouble your house (Matheo) but as Dutchmen
do in Taverns (drink, be merry, and be gone.)

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
Indeed if you be right Dutchmen, if you fall to drinking
you must be gone.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
The worst is, my wife is not at home; but we will fly
hie (my generous Knight) for all that:there is no Music
when a woman is in the consort.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: No, for she is like a pair of Virginals,
Always with Iackes at her tail.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: See, the Covey is sprung.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Save you Gallants.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Happily encountered, sweet bloods.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
Gentlemen, you all know Seignior Candido, the Linen
Draper, he that is more patient than a brown Baker, upon
the day when he heats his Oven, and has forty Scolds about
him.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Yes, we know him all, what of him?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
Would it not be a good fit of mirth, to make a piece
of English cloth of him, and to stretch him on the Tainters,
till the threads of his own natural humour crack, by making
him drink healths, Tobacco dance, sing bawdy songs,
or to run any bias according as we think good to cast him?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: It were a Morris dance worth the seeing.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p:
But the old Fox is so crafty, we shall hardly hunt out
of his den.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
To that train I have given fire already; and the hook
to draw him hither, is to see certain pieces of Lawn,
which I told him I have to sell, and indeed have such: fetch
them down, Pacheco.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
Yes, sir, I am your Water-spaniel, and will fetch anything:
but I will fetch one dish of meat anon, shall turn your
stomach, and that is a Constable.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: How now? how now?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: What Galley foist is this?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
Peace, two dishes of stewed prunes, a Bawd and a
Pander. My worthy Lieutenant Bots; why, now I see thou art
a man of thy word, welcome; welcome Mistress Horsleach:
Pray Gentlemen, salute this reverend Matron.

sp.speaker: Hors.
sp.p: Thanks to all your Worships.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
I bade a Drawer send in wine too: did none come
along with thee (Grandam) but the Lieutenant?

sp.speaker: Hors.
sp.p:
None came along with me but Bots, if it like your
Worship.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.p: Who the pox should come along with you but Bots?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: O brave! march fair.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Are you come? that is well.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Here is Ordnance able to sack a City.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Come, repeat, read this Inventory.

sp.speaker: 1. Uint.
sp.p:
Imprimis, a pottle of Greeke wine, a pottle of
Peter sa meene, a pottle of Charnico, and a pottle of Ziattica.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: You are paid?

sp.speaker: 2. Uint.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: So shall some of us be anon, I fear.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.p:
Here is a hot day towards: but s'wounds, this is the
life out of which a Soldier sucks sweetness, when this Artillery
goes off roundly, some must drop to the ground: Cannon,
Demy-cannon, Saker, and Basilisk.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Give fire, Lieutenant.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.p:
So, so: Must I venture first upon the breach? to you
all, Gallants: Bots sets upon you all.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p:
It is hard (Bots) if we pepper not you, as well as
you pepper us.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
My noble Linen Draper! Some wine: Welcome
old Lad.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: You are welcome, Seignior.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: These Lawns, sir?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
Presently, my man is gone for them: we have rigged
a Fleet, you see here, to sail about the world.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: A dangerous Voyage, sailing in such Ships.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.p: There is no casting overboard yet.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
Because you are an old Lady, I will have you be acquainted
with this grave Citizen, pray bestow your lips
upon him, and bid him welcome.

sp.speaker: Hors.
sp.p:
Any Citizen shall be most welcome to me: -- I
have used to buy ware at your shop.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: It may be so, good Madam.

sp.speaker: Hors.
sp.p:
Your Prentices know my dealings well; I trust
your good wife be in good case: if it please you, bear her a
token from my lips, by word of mouth.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p:
I pray no more forsooth, it is very well, indeed I
love no sweet meats: -- She has a breath stinks worse than
fifty Polecats. Sir, a word, is she a Lady?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
A woman of a good house, and an ancient, she is a
Bawd.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p:
A Bawd? Sir, I will steal hence, and see your
Lawns some other time.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
Steal out of such company? Pacheco? my man is
but gone for them: Lieutenant Bots, drink to this worthy old
fellow, and teach him to fly hie.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Swagger: and make him do it on his knees.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p:
How, Bots? now bless me, what do I with Bots?
no wine in sooth, no wine, good Master Bots.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.p:
Gray-beard, Goats pizzle: it is a health, have this
in your guts, or this, there: I will sing a bawdy song, sir, because
your vergis face is melancholy, to make liquor go
down glib: will you fall on your marrowbones, and pledge
this health, it is to my Mistress, a whore?

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p:
Here is Ratsbane upon Ratsbane: Master Bots, I
pray, sir, pardon me: you are a Soldier, press me not to this
service, I am old, and shoot not in such pot-guns.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.p: Cap, I will teach you.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p:
To drink healths, is to drink sickness: Gentlemen,
pray rescue me.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.p: S'wounds, who dare?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: We shall have stabbing then?

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: I have reckonings to cast up, good Master Bots.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.p: This will make you cast them up better.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Why does your hand shake so?

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: The palsy, Seigniors, danceth in my blood.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.p:
Pipe with a pox, sir, then, or I will make your blood
dance --

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: Hold, hold, good Master Bots, I drink.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: To whom?

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: To the old Countess there.

sp.speaker: Hors.
sp.p:
To me, old Boy? this is he that never drunk wine:
once again to it.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: With much ado the poison is got down,
Though I can scarce get up; never before
Drank I a whores health, nor will never more.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Hast been at Gallows?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Yes, sir, for I make account to suffer today.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Look, Seignior: here is the Commodity.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: Your price?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Thus.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: No: too dear: thus.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
No: O fie, you must sly higher: yet take them home,
trifles shall not make us quarrel, we will agree, you shall have
them, and a pennyworth, I will fetch money at your shop.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: Be it so, good Seignior, send me going.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Going? a deep bowl of wine for Seignior Candido.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: He would be going.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: I will rather stay, than go so: stop your Bowl.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: How now?

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.p: Is it Shrove tuesday, that these Ghosts walk.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: What is your business, Sir?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p:
From the Duke: you are the man we look for,
Seignior, I have Warrant here from the Duke, to apprehend
you upon felony for robbing two Peddlers: I charge you
in the Dukes name go quickly.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
Is the wind turned? well: this is that old Wolf,
my Father-in-law: seek out your Mistress, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Yes, Sir: as shafts by piecing are made strong,
So shall thy life be straightened by this wrong.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: In troth we are sorry.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
Brave men must be crossed, pish, it is but Fortunes
Dice roving against me: Come, sir, pray use me like a Gentleman,
let me not be carried through the streets like a Pageant.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p:
If these Gentlemen please, you shall go along
with them.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Be it so: come.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: What are you, sir?

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.p:
I, sir? sometimes a figure, sometimes a cipher, as the
State has occasion to cast up her accounts: I am a Soldier.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Your name is Bots, is it not?

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.p: Bots is my name, Bots is known to this Company.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: I know you are, Sir: what is she?

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.p: A Gentlewoman, my Mother.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Take them both along.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.p: Me? Sir.

sp.speaker: Billmen.
sp.p: And Sir.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: If he swagger, raise the street.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.p: Gentlemen, Gentlemen, whither will you drag us?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: To the Garden house. Bots, are we even with you?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: To Bridewell with them.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.p: You will answer this.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p:
Better than a challenge, I have warrant for my
work, sir.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: We will go before.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Pray do.

Who, Seignior Candido? a Citizen of your degree consorted
thus, and revelling in such a house?

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: Why, sir? what house I pray?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Lewd, and defamed.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: Is it so? thanks, sir: I am gone.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: What have you there?

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p:
Lawns which I bought, sir, of the Gentleman
that keeps the house.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p:
And I have warrant here, to search for such stolen
Ware: these Lawns are stolen.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p:
So he is the Thief, you the Receiver: I am sorry for
this chance, I must commit you.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: Me, sir, for what?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p:
These Goods are found upon you, and you must
answer it.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: Must I so?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Most certain.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: I will send for Bail.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p:
I dare not: yet because you are a Citizen of worth,
you shall not be made a pointing stock, but without Guard
pass only with myself.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: To Bridewell too?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: No remedy.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p:
Yes, patience: being not mad, they had me once to Bedlam,
Now I am drawn to Bridewell, loving no Whores.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: You will buy Lawn? --

div1.stage: Enter at one doore Hipollito; at another, Lodouico, Astolfo, Carolo, Beraldo, Fontinell.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
Yonder is the Lord Hipollito, by any means leave
him and me together: Now will I turn him to a Madman.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Save you, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: I have strange news to tell you.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: What are they?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Your Mare is in the pound.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: How is this?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Your Nightingale is in a Limebush.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Ha?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Your Puritanical Honest Whore sits in a blue gown.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Blue Gown!

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
She will chalk out your way to her now: she beats
chalk.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Where, who dares?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
Do you know the Brick-house of Castigation, by
the River side that runs by Millan: the School where
they pronounce no letter well but O?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: I know it not.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
Any man that has borne Office of Constable, or any
woman that has fallen from a Horse-load to a Cart-load, or
like an old Hen that has had none but rotten eggs in her
nest, can direct you to her: there you shall see your Punk
amongst her back-friends, there you may have her at your will, for there she beats Chalk, or grinds in the Mill, with
a whip deedle, deedle, deedle, deedle; ah little monkey.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p:
What Rogue durst serve that Warrant, knowing I
loved her?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Some Worshipful Rascal, I lay my life.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: I will beat the Lodgings down about their ears That are her Keepers.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: So you may bring an old house over her head.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: I will to her --
I will to her, stood armed Fiends to guard the doors.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: O me! what Monsters are men made by whores?
If this false fire do kindle him,there is one Faggot
More to the bonfire, now to my Bridewell Birds,
What Song will they sing?

div1.stage: Enter Duke, Carolo, Astolfo, Beraldo, Fontinell, three or foure Masters of Bridewell: Infælice.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Your Bridewell? that the name? for beauty, strength,
Capacity and form of ancient building,
(Besides the Rivers neighbourhood) few houses
Wherein we keep our Court can better it.

sp.speaker: 1. Master.
sp.l: Hither from foreign Courts have Princes come,
And with our Duke did Acts of State Commence,
Here that great Cardinal had first audience,
(The grave Campaign,) that Duke dead, his Son
(That famous Prince) gave free possession
Of this his Palace, to the Citizens,
To be the poor man's ware-house: and endowed it
With Lands to the value of seven hundred mark,
With all the bedding and the furniture, once proper
(As the Lands then were) to an Hospital
Belonging to a Duke of Sauoy. Thus
Fortune can toss the World, a Princes Court
Is thus a prison now.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: It is Fortunes sport:
These changes common are: the Wheel of Fate
Turns Kingdoms up, till they fall desolate.
But how are these seven hundred Marks by the year
Employed in this your Workhouse?

sp.speaker: 1. Master.
sp.l: War and Peace
Feed both upon those Lands: when the Iron doors
Of wars burst open, from this House are sent
Men furnished in all Martial Complement.
The Moon hath through her Bow scarce drawn to the head,
(Like to twelve silver Arrows) all the Months,
Since 1600. Soldiers went aboard:
Here Providence and Charity play such parts,
The House is like a very School of Arts,
For when our Soldiers (like Ships driven from Sea,
With ribs all broken, and with tattered sides,)
Cast anchor here again, their ragged backs
How often do we cover? that (like men)
They may be sent to their own Homes again.
All here are but one swarm of Bees, and strive
To bring with wearied thighs honey to the Hive.
The sturdy Beggar, and the lazy Lown,
Gets here hard hands, or laced Correction.
The Vagabond grows stayed, and learns to obey,
The Drone is beaten well, and sent away
As other prisons are, (some for the Thief,
Some, by which undone Credit gets relief
From bridled Debtors; others for the poor)
So this is for the Bawd, the Rogue, and Whore.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: An excellent Team of Horse.

sp.speaker: 1. Master.
sp.l: Nor is it seen,
That the whip draws blood here, to cool the Spleen
Of any rugged Bencher: nor does offence
Feele smart, or spiteful, or rash evidence:
But pregnant testimony forth must stand,
Ere Justice leave them in the Beadles hand,
As Iron, on the Anvil are they laid,
Not to take blows alone, but to be made
And fashioned to some Charitable use.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l:
Thus wholesomest Laws spring from the worst
abuse.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Let mercy touch your heart-strings (gracious Lord)
That it may sound like music in the ear
Of a man desperate, (being in the hands of Law.)

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: His name?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Matheo.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: For a robbery? where is she?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: In this House.

div1.stage: Exit Bel. and one of the Masters of Bridewell.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Fetch you him hither --
Is this the Party?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
This is the Hen, my Lord, that the Cock (with the
Lordly comb) your Son-in-law would crow over, and
tread.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Are your two Servants ready?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: My two Peddlers are packed together, my good Lord.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: It is well: this day in Judgment shall be spent,
Vice (like a wound lanced) mends by punishment.

sp.speaker: Infæ..
sp.l: Let me be gone, my Lord, or stand unseen;
It is rare when a Judge strikes, and that none die,
And it is unfit then, women should be by.

sp.speaker: 1. Master.
sp.p: We will place you, Lady, in some private room.

sp.speaker: Infæ..
sp.p: Pray do so.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.l: Thus nice Dames swear, it is unfit their eyes
Should view men carved up for Anatomies,
Yet they will see all, so they may stand unseen,
Many women sure will sin behind a Screen.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Your Son (the Lord Hipollito) is entered.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Tell him we wish his presence. A word Storsa:
On what wings flew he hither?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
These, I told him -- his Lark whom he loved, was
a Bridewell Bird, he is mad that this Cage should hold her,
and is come to let her out.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: It is excellent: away, go call him hither.

div1.stage:
Enter one of the Gouernours of the House, Bellafront after him
with Matheo, after him the Constable. Enter at another
doore, Lodouico and Hipollito: Orlando steps
forth and brings in two Pedlers.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: You are to us a stranger (worthy Lord)
It is strange to see you here.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: It is most fit,
That where the Sun goes, Atomies follow it.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Atomies neither shape, nor honour bear:
Be you yourself, a Sunbeam to shine clear.
Is this the Gentleman? Stand forth and hear your accusation.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
I will hear none: I fly hie in that: rather than Kites
shall seize upon me, and pick out mine eyes to my face, I will
strike my talons through mine own heart first, and spit my
blood in theirs: I am here for shriving those two fools of
their sinful pack: when those Jackdaws have cawed over
me, then must I cry guilty, or not guilty; the Law has
work enough already, and therefore I will put no work of
mine into his hands, the Hangman shall have it first, I did pluck
those Ganders, did rob them.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: It is well done to confess.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
Confess and be hanged, and then I fly hie, is it not
so? that for that a gallows is the worst rub that a good
Bowler can meet with: I stumbled against such a post, else
this night I had played the part of a true Son in these days,
undone my Father-in-law, with him would I have run at leapfrog,
and come over his gold, though I had broke his neck
for it: but the poor Salmon Trout is now in the Net.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: And now the Law must teach you to fly hie.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
Right, my Lord, and then may you fly low; no more
words, a Mouse, Mum, you are stopped.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Be good to my poor husband, dear my Lords.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
Ass, why shouldst thou pray them to be good to
me, when no man here is good to one another?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Did any hand work in this theft but yours?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
O, yes, my Lord, yes: -- the Hangman has never
one Son at a birth, his Children always come by couples:
Though I cannot give the old dog, my Father, a bone to gnaw.
the Daughter shall be sure of a Choke-pear. -- Yes, my
Lord, there was one more that fiddled my fine Peddlers, and
that was my wife.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Alas, I?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: O everlasting, supernatural superlative Villain!

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Your wife, Matheo?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Sure it cannot be.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
O, Sir, you love no quarters of Mutton
that hang
up, you love none but whole Mutton; she set the robbery, I
performed it; she spurred me on, I galloped away.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: My Lords.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: My Lords, (fellow give me speech) if my poor life
may ransom thine, I yield it to the Law,
Thou hurtest thy soul (yet wipest off no offence)
By casting blots upon my Innocence:
Let not these spare me, but tell truth: no, see
Who slips his neck out of the misery,
Though not out of the mischief: let thy Servant
That shared in this base Act, accuse me here,
Why should my Husband perish, he go clear?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: A god Child, hang thine own Father.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Old fellow, was thy hand in too?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
My hand was in the Pie, my Lord, I confess it: my
Mistress I see, will bring me to the Gallows, and so leave me;
but I will not leave her so: I had rather hang in a woman's company,
than in a man's; because if we should go to hell together,
I should scarce be let in, for all the Devils are afraid to
have any women come amongst them, as I am true Thief,
she neither consented to this felony, nor knew of it.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: What fury prompts thee on to kill thy wife?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
It is my humour, Sir, it is a foolish Bag-pipe that I
make myself merry with: why should I eat hemp-seed
at the Hangman's thirteen pence halfpenny Ordinary,
and have this whore laugh at me as I swing, as I totter?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Is she a Whore?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: A sixpenny Mutton Pasty, for any to cut up.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Ah, Toad, Toad, Toad.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
A Barbers Cittern for every Serving-man to play
upon, that Lord, your Son, knows it.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: I, sir, am I her Bawd then?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: No, sir, but she is your Whore then,

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Yea Spider, dost catch at great Flies?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: My Whore?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
I cannot talk, sir, and tell of your Rems, and your
rees, and your whirligigs, and devices: but, my Lord, I
found them like Sparrows in one nest, billing together, and
bulling of me, I took them in bed, was ready to kill him was
up to stab her --

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Close thy rank Jaws: pardon me, I am vexed,
Thou art a Villain, a malicious Devil,
Deep as the place where thou art lost, thou liest,
Since I am thus far got into this storm,
I will through, and thou shalt see I will through untouched,
When thou shalt perish in it.

sp.speaker: Infæ..
sp.l: It is my cue
To enter now: room, let my Prize be played,
I have lurked in Clouds, yet heard what all have said,
What Jury more can prove, she has wronged my bed,
Then her own husband, she must be punished;
I challenge Law, my Lord, Letters, and Gold, and Jewels
From my Lord that woman took.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Against that black mouthed Devil, against Letters, and Gold,
And against a jealous Wife I do uphold,
Thus far her reputation, I could sooner
Shake the Appenine, and crumble Rocks to dust,
Than (though Ioues shower rained down) tempt her to lust.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: What shall I say?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
Say thou art not a Whore, and that is more than
fifteen women (amongst five hundred) dare swear without
lying: this shalt thou say, no let me say it for thee; thy
Husband is a Knave, this Lord is an honest Man; thou art no
Punk, this Lady is a right Lady. Pacheco is a Thief as his
Master is, but old Orlando is a true a man as thy Father is:
I have seen you fly hie, sir, and I have seen you fly low, sit, and to
keep you from the Gallows, sir, a blue Coat have I worn,
and a Thief did I turn, mine own men are the Peddlers, my
twenty pound did fly hie, sir, your wives Gown did fly
low, sir: whither fly you now, sir? you have scaped the Gallows,
to the Devil you fly next, sir. Am I right, my Liege?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Your Father has the true Physician played.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: And I am now his Patient.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p:
And be so still, it is a good sign when our cheeks
blush at ill.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: The Linen Draper (Seignior Candido)
He whom the City terms the Patient man,
Is likewise here for buying of those Lawns
The Peddlers lost.

sp.speaker: Infæ..
sp.p: Alas good Candido.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Fetch him: and when these payments up are cast,
Weigh out your light Gold, but let us have them last.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: In Bridewell, Candido?

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: Yes, my good Lord.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: What make you here?

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: My Lord, what make you here?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I am here to save right, and to drive wrong hence.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: And I to bear wrong here with patience.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: You have bought stolen Goods.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: So they do say, my Lord,
Yet bought I them upon a Gentleman's word,
And Imagine now, as I thought then,
That there be Thieves, but no Thieves Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Your Credit is cracked being here.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: No more than Gold
Being cracked which does his estimation hold.
I was in Bedlam once, but was I mad?
They made me pledge Whores healths, but am I bad,
Because I am with bad people?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Well, stand by,
If you take wrong, we will cure the injury.

div1.stage:
Enter Constable, after them Bots, after him two Beadles, one
with Hempe, the other with a Beetle.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Stay, stay, what is he? a prisoner?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: He seems a Soldier?

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.p:
I am what I seem, Sir, one of Fortunes Bastards, a
Soldier, and a Gentleman, and am brought in here with
Master Constables band of Bilmen, because they face me
down that I live (like those that keep Bowling-alleys)
by the sins of the people, in being a Squire of the body.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: O, an Apple-squire.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.p:
Yes, sir, that degree of scurvy Squires, and that I am
maintained by the best part that is commonly in a woman,
by the worst players of those parts, but I am known to all
this company.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
My Lord, it is true, we all know him, it is Lieutenant
Bots.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Bots, and where have you served, Bots?

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.p:
In most of your hottest Services in the Low-countries:
at the Groin I was wounded in this thigh, and halted
upon it, but it is now sound. In Cleueland I missed but little,
having the bridge of my nose broken down with two
great stones, as I was scaling a Fort: I have been tried, Sir,
too, in Gelderland, and scaped hardly there from being blown
up at a Breach: I was fired, and lay in the Surgeons hands
for it, till the fall of the leafe following.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: All this may be, and yet you no Soldier.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.p:
No Soldier, sir? I hope these are Services that your
proudest Commanders do venture upon, and never come
off sometimes.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Well, sir, because you say you are a Soldier,
I will use you like a Gentleman: make room there,
Plant him amongst you, we shall have anon
Strange Hawks fly here before us: if none light on you,
You shall with freedom take your flight:
But if you prove a Bird of baser wing.
We will use you like such Birds, here you shall sing.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.p: I wish to be tried at no other weapon.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Why, is he furnished with those implements?

sp.speaker: 1. Master.
sp.l: The Pander is more dangerous to a State,
Than is the common Thief, and though our laws
Lie heavier on the Thief, yet that the Pander
May know the Hangman's ruff should fit him too,
Therefore he is set to beat Hemp.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: This does savour
Of Justice, basest Slaves to basest labour.
Now pray, set open Hell, and let us see
The She-Devils that are here.

sp.speaker: Infæ..
sp.l: Methinks this place
Should make even Lais honest.

sp.speaker: 1. Master.
sp.l: Some it turns good,
But (as some men whose hands are once in blood,
Do in a pride spill more) so, some going hence,
Are (by being here) lost in more impudence:
Let it not to them (when they come) appear,
That any one does as their Judge sit here:
But that as Gentlemen you come to see,
And then perhaps their tongues will walk more free.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Let them be marshalled in: be covered all,
Fellows, now to make the Scene more Comical.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Will not you be smelt out, Bots.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.p: No, your bravest whores have the worst noses.

div1.stage:
Enter two of the Masters: a Constable after them, then Dorathea
Target, braue, after her two Beadles, th'one with a wheele, the other with a
blue Gowne.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Are not you a Bride, forsooth?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Say ye?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: He would know if these be not your Bridemen.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p:
Uh, yes, sir: and look ye, do you see the Bride-laces
that I give at my wedding, will serve to tie Rosemary
to both your Coffins when you come from hanging-Scab?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Fie, Punk, fie, fie, fie.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p:
Out you stale stinking head of Garlic, foh, at my
heels.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: My head is cloven.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: O, let the Gentlewoman alone, she is going to shrift.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: Nay to do penance.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Aye, aye go Punk, go to the Cross and be whipped.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p:
Marry mew, marry muff, marry hang you goodman
Dog: whipped? do ye take me for a base Spittle whore? in troth
Gentlemen, you wear the clothes of Gentlemen, but
you carry not the minds of Gentlemen, to abuse a Gentlewoman
of my fashion.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Fashion? pox on your fashions, art not a whore?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Goodman Slave.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: O fie, abuse her not, let us two talk,
What mought I call your name, pray?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p:
I am not ashamed of my name, Sir, my name is Mistress
Doll Target, a Western Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Her Target against any Pike in Millan.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Why is this wheel borne after her?

sp.speaker: 1. Master.
sp.l: She must spin.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: A coarse thread it shall be, as all threads are.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: If you spin, then you will earn money here too?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p:
I had rather get half a Crown abroad, than ten
Crowns here.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Abroad? I think so.

sp.speaker: Infæ..
sp.p: Dost thou not weep now thou art here?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p:
Say ye? weep? yes forsooth, as you did when
you lost your Maidenhead: do you not hear how I weep?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Farewell Doll.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Farewell Dog.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Past shame: past penitence, why is that blue Gown?

sp.speaker: 1. Master.
sp.l: Being stripped out of her wanton loose attire,
That Garment she puts on, base to the eye,
Only to clothe her in humility.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Are all the rest like this?

sp.speaker: 1. Master.
sp.l: No, my good Lord.
You see, this Drab swells with a wanton rein,
The next that enters has a different strain.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Variety is good, let us see the rest.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.p: Your Grace sees I am sound yet, and no Bullets hit me.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Come off so, and it is well.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Here is the second Mess

div1.stage:
Enter the two Masters, after them the Constable, after him
Penelope Whore-hound, like a Cittizens wife, after her two
Beadles, one with a blue Gowne, another with
Chalke and a Mallet.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p:
I have worn many a costly Gown, but I was never
thus guarded with blue Coats, and Beadles, and Constables,
and -- --

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Alas fair Mistress, spoil not thus your eyes.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p:
O sweet sir, I fear the spoiling of other places about
me that are dearer than my eyes; if you be Gentlemen,
if you be men, or ever came of a woman, pity my case, stand
to me, stick to me, good sir, you are an old man.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
Hang not on me, I prithee, old Trees bear no such
fruit.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Will you bail me, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Bail thee, art in for debt?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p:
No -- is my Judge, sir, I am in for no debts, I paid
my Taylor for this Gown, the last five shillings a week
that was behind, yesterday.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: What is your name, I pray?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p:
Penelope Whore-hound, I come of the Whore-hounds.
How does Lieutenant Bots.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Ah ha Bots.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.p: A very honest woman, as I am a Soldier, a pox Bots ye.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p:
I was never in this pickle before, and yet if I go amongst
Citizens wives, they jeer at me: if I go among
the Loose-bodied Gowns, they cry a pox on me, because I
go civilly attired, and swear their trade was a good
trade, till such as I am took it out of their hands: good
Lieutenant Bots, speak to these Captains to bail me.

sp.speaker: 1. Master.
sp.p:
Begging for bail still? you are a trim gossip, go
give her the blue Gown, set her to her char, work Housewife,
for your bread, away.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p:
Out you Dog, a pox on you all, women are born to
curse thee, but I shall live to see twenty such flat-caps shaking
Dice for a penny-worth of Pippins: out, you blue-eyed
Rogue.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Even now she wept, and prayed, now does she curse?

sp.speaker: 1. Master.
sp.p:
Seeing me: if still she had staid, this had been
worse.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Was she ever here before?

sp.speaker: 1. Master.
sp.p: Five times at least,

And thus if men come to her, have her eyes wrung, and
wept out her bail.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Bots, you know her?

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.p:
Is there any Gentleman here, that knows not a
Whore, and is he a hair the worse for that?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Is she a City-dame, she is so attired?

sp.speaker: 1. Master.
sp.l: No, my good Lord, that is only but the vail
To her loose body, I have seen her here
In gayer Masking Suits, as several Sauces
Give one Dish several Tastes, so change of Habits
In Whores is a bewitching Art: today she is all in
Colours to besot Gallants, then in modest black,
To catch the Citizen, and this from their Examinations
Drawn, now shall you see a Monster both in shape
And nature quite from these, that sheds no tear,
Nor yet is nice, it is a plain ramping Bear,
Many such Whales are cast upon this Shore.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Let us see her.

sp.speaker: 1. Master.
sp.p: Then behold a swaggering Whore.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Keep your ground, Bots.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.p:
I do but traverse to spy advantage how to arm
myself.

div1.stage:
Enter the two Masters first, after them the Constable, after them a
Beadle beating a Bason, then Catyryna Bountinall, with
Mistris Horsleach, after them another Beadle with a
blue head guarded with yellow.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.p:
Sirrah, when I cry hold your hands, hold, you Rogue.
Catcher, hold: Bawd, are the French Chilblains in your
heels, that you can come no faster? are not you (Bawd) a
Whores Ancient, and must not I follow my Colours?

sp.speaker: Hors.
sp.p:
O Mistress Katherine, you do me wrong to accuse
me here as you do, before the right Worshipful: I am
known for a motherly honest woman, and no Bawd.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.p:
Marry, foh, honest? burnt at fourteen, seven times
whipped, six times carted, nine times ducked, searched by
some hundred and fifty Constables, and yet you are honest?
Honest Mistress Horsleach, is this World, a World to keep
Bawds and Whores honest? How many times hast thou
given Gentlemen a quart of wine in a gallon pot? how many
twelve-penny Fees, nay two shillings Fees, nay, when
any Ambassadors have been here, how many half crown
Fees hast thou taken? how many Carriers hast thou bribed
for Country Wenches? how often have I rinsed your lungs
in Aqua uitæ, and yet you are honest?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: And what were you the whilst?

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.p:
Marry hang you, Master Slave, who made you an
examiner?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Well said, belike this Devil spares no man.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.p: What art thou prithee?

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.p: Nay what art thou prithee?

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.p: A Whore, art thou a Thief?

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.p:
A Thief, no, I defy the calling, I am a Soldier,
have borne Arms in the Field, been in many a hot Skirmish,
yet come off sound.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.p:
Sound with a pox to ye, ye abominable Rogue!
you a Soldier? you in Skirmishes? where? amongst pottle
pots in a Bawdy-house? Look, look here, you Madam
Worm eaten, do not you know him?

sp.speaker: Hors.
sp.p:
Lieutenant Bots, where have ye been this many a
day?

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.p:
Old Bawd, do not discredit me, seem not to
know me.

sp.speaker: Hors.
sp.p:
Not to know ye, Master Bots? as long as I have
breath, I cannot forget thy sweet face.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Why, do you know him? he says he is a Soldier.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.p:
He a Soldier? a Pander, a Dog that will lick up six
pence: do ye hear, you Master Swines snout, how long is it
since you held the door for me, and cried to it again, nobody
comes, ye Rogue you?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, you are smelt out again, Bots.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.p:
Pox ruin her nose for it, if I be not revenged for
this -- um ye Bitch.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
Do ye hear ye, Madam? why does your Ladyship
swagger thus? you are very brave, methinks.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Not at your cost, Master Cods-head,
Is any man here bleary-eyed to see me brave?

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Yes, I am,
Because good Clothes upon a Whores back
Is like fair painting upon a rotten wall.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.p:
Marry muff Master Whoremaster, you come upon
me with sentences.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: By this light has small sense for it.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: O fie, fie, do not vex her.
And yet methinks a creature of more scurvy conditions
Should not know what a good Petticoat were.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.p: Marry come out,

You are so busy about my Petticoat, you will creep up to my
placket, if ye could but attain the honour, but if the
outsides offend your Rogueships, look on the lining, it is
Silk.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Is it Silk it is lined with then?

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.p:
Silk? I Silk, Master Slave, you would be glad to
wipe your nose with the skirt on it: this it is to come among
a company of Cods-heads that know not how to use
a Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Tell her the Duke is here.

sp.speaker: 1. Master.
sp.p: Be modest, Kate, the Duke is here.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.p:
If the Devil were here, I care not: set forward, ye
Rogues, and give attendance according to your places, let
Bawds and Whores be sad, for I will sing if the Devil were
a-dying.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Why before her does the Basin ring?

sp.speaker: 1. Master.
sp.l: It is an emblem of their revelling,
The whips we use lets forth their wanton blood,
Making them calm, and more to calm their pride,
Instead of Coaches they in Carts do ride.
Will your Grace see more of this bad Ware?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: No, shut up shop, we will now break up the fair,
Yet ere we part -- you, sir, that take upon ye
The name of Soldier, that true name of worth,
Which, action not vain boasting best sets forth,
To let you know how far a Soldiers name
Stands from your title, and to let you see,
Soldiers must not be wronged where Princes be:
This be your sentence.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Defend yourself, Bots.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: First, all the private sufferance that the house
Inflicts upon Offenders, you (as the basest)
Shall undergo it double, after which
You shall be whipped, sir, round about the City,
Then banished from the Land.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.p: Beseech your Grace.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Away with him, see it done, Panders and Whores
Are City-plagues, which being kept alive,
Nothing that looks like goodness ever can thrive.
Now good Orlando, what say you to your bad Son-in-law?

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
Marry this, my Lord, he is my Son-in-law, and in
law will I be his Father: for if law can pepper him, he shall
be so parboiled, that he shall stink no more in the nose of the
Common-wealth.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Be yet more kind and merciful, good Father.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
Dost thou beg for him, thou precious man's meat,
thou? has he not beaten thee, kicked thee, trod on thee, and
dost thou fawn on him like his Spaniel? has he not
pawned thee to thy Petticoat, sold thee to thy smock, made
ye leap at a crust, yet wouldst have me save him?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: O yes, good sir, women shall learn of me,
To love their husbands in greatest misery,
Then show him pity, or you wrack myself.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
Have ye eaten Pigeons that you are so kind-hearted
to your Mate? Nay, you are a couple of wild Bears, I will
have ye both baited at one stake: but as for this Knave, the
Gallows is thy due, and the Gallows thou shalt have, I will
have justice of the Duke, the Law shall have thy life, what,
dost thou hold him? let go his hand: if thou dost not forsake
him, a Fathers everlasting blessing fall upon both your
heads: away, go, kiss out of my sight, play thou the
Whore no more, nor thou the Thief again, my house shall
be thine, my meat shall be thine, and so shall my wine, but
my money shall be mine, and yet when I die, (so thou dost
not fly hie) take all, yet good Matheo, mend.
sp.l: Thus for joy weeps Orlando, and doth end.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Then hear, Matheo: all your woes are stayed
By your good Father-in-law: all your Ills
Are clear purged from you by his working pills.
Come Seignior Candido, these green young wits
(We see by Circumstance) this plot hath laid,
Still to provoke thy patience, they find
A wall of Brass, no Armour is like the mind;
Thou hast taught the City patience, now our Court
Shall be thy Sphere, where from thy good report,
Rumours this truth unto the world shall sing,
A Patient man is a Pattern for a King.
